dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It nearly fills the screen, swimming mysteriously in the warm late summer air. SOUND: Crickets.

dialogues.speaker: CREDITS BEGIN.
dialogues.text: A rail-rider comes chugging along the tracks. Aboard is ARNIE WESTRUM, a big man in a strappy T-shirt and chino pants. He is drinking beer. ARNIE (sings) My beer is Rheingold the dry beer... Think of Rheingold whenever you buy beer... He drains the rest of his own bottle of Rheingold and tos it to one side. Up ahead we see a switching point. ARNIE throws the rail-rider into neutral, opens the toolb on the back, and brings out a big five-cell flashlight. H shines it on the switch. He gets a crowbar from the toolbox, plus a big wrench, a pair of pliers, a hammer, and a pair of work gloves. He a gets another bottle of beer and sticks it into his back pocket. ARNIE jumps down and approaches the switch. CREDITS CONTINUE.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ARNIE, AT THE SWITCHING POINT NIGHT
dialogues.text: He drops his tools, pulls on his work gloves, and trains light on the switch for a moment. During this: ARNIE (sings) It's not bitter, not sweet, it's a real frosty treat, won't you try, won't you buy Rheingold beer... He tries the switch. No go. It's frozen.

dialogues.speaker: ARNIE
dialogues.text: Stuck tighter'n dogshit in a deep freeze! He takes the bottle of beer from his back pocket and fish a churchkey from one of the front ones. He pops the cap a drinks deeply. He burps. Then he screws the half-empty bottle of beer into the cinders so it won't fall over. Th he picks up his crowbar. CREDITS CONTINUE.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE RAIL-RIDER NIGHT
dialogues.text: There's a SOUND of bushes shaking. Something comes out - something huge. It leaps limberly onto the rail-rider. It a werewolf with greenish-yellow eyes. Tatters of clothes still hang from it. What kind of monster, exactly? It is humanoid as well as wolfish... and when we learn who it is in its human form, should be able to spot the resemblance at once...and kick ourselves for not knowing earlier. It crouches there, huge and bushy and fanged and deadly, the whole rail-rider. CREDITS CONCLUDE.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ARNIE NIGHT
dialogues.text: He's working the crowbar into the junction point just as hard as he can. Swearing at it under his breath. Suddenly both the tracks and the switch move.

dialogues.speaker: ARNIE
dialogues.text: Hot damn! Now... a little oil... He turns back toward the rail-rider.

dialogues.speaker: ARNIE
dialogues.text: It's not bitter, not sweet... it's a big fuckin' treat... A NOISE - bushes rattling; cinders clinking and rattling. ARNIE looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing there. His bottle of beer stands by the litter of his tools.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ARNIE, AT THE RAIL-RIDER NIGHT
dialogues.text: He's rooting around in the toolbox, back to the switching point.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ARNIE'S BOTTLE OF BEER, CU NIGHT
dialogues.text: A hairy hand/paw closes around it - we see huge curved cl on that hand.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE WEREWOLF'S FACE, CU NIGHT
dialogues.text: Glaring green-yellow eyes; a savage, beastial face which still half human. That's all we see. The rest is in shado It opens its mouth and upends the bottle of beer. Foamy Rheingold begins gurgling down the werewolf's throat.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ARNIE AT THE RAIL-RIDER NIGHT
dialogues.text: He comes up with an old-fashioned oilcan, the kind with t long spout. He starts back to the switching point, waving the can. ARNIE (sings) My beer is Rheingold the dry beer... Think of Rheingold whenever you fry beer... He arrives, looks down... and stops singing. His eyes wid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see the hole where ARNIE put his beer, but it is o course empty. Beside it are two huge prints in the cinder half wolf, half human.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ARNIE NIGHT
dialogues.text: He's beginning to be afraid. Beginning to look around to what might be out here with him. Beginning to realize he in extremely deep shit.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE WEREWOLF NIGHT
dialogues.text: It rises up on its hind legs, eyes glaring an ugly yellow green. Its snout wrinkles back, revealing those teeth.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ARNIE NIGHT
dialogues.text: He's craning back to look at the thing, his face a grue o horror.

dialogues.speaker: ARNIE
dialogues.text: Oh n- A huge clawed hand/paw comes sweeping down. ARNIE's head granted an immediate Reno-style divorce from the rest of body.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE RAIL-RIDER NIGHT
dialogues.text: SOUND of the beast approaching. A hairy arm and taloned h reaches into the toolbox bolted to the back and rummages. The hand is dripping blood. It comes up with a bottle of Rheingold. The WEREWOLF begins to sing. It is a bizarre funny-horrib grunting, the words hellishly recognizable. WEREWOLF (gutteral; subhuman) My beer is Rheingold the dry beer... No bottle opener for this thing; it brings the neck of th bottle down sharply on the edge of the toolbox. Beer foam out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE WEREWOLF'S FACE, IN DEEP SHADOW NIGHT
dialogues.text: He/It rams the jagged neck of the bottle deep into its mo and drinks. Foam drizzles down its pelt. It's grinning. WEREWOLF (snarling voice) Think of Rheingold whenever you buy beer...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE WEREWOLF, CU NIGHT
dialogues.text: The bottle is empty. There are CRUNCHING SOUNDS as it beg to eat the bottle. Blood begins to run out of its mouth; its face wrinkles i pain and fury. It spits out broken, bloody jags of glass. Looks up. It HOWLS.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TARKER'S MILLS NIGHT
dialogues.text: We're looking at Main Street of a small country town - mi be New England, might be mid-South. Might be 1984, might 1981. This is Tarker's Mills, and in places like this, ti moves more slowly. Cars - not too many - move back and forth. No one is in a hurry. We see the Methodist church (and the parsonage next door) Andy's Sporting Goods; Owen's Pub, with its Narragansett neon sign. We see a barber shop with a striped pole; we s the Holy Family Catholic Church and the rectory next door We see the Gem Theater, which is showing a revival of Sop Loren in "Two Women." It's Our Town, U.S.A. JANE (voice-over) This place is Tarker's Mills, where I grew up... and this is how it was when I was fourteen - a place where people cared about each other as much as they cared about themselves. This is how my town looked as, all unknowing, it approached the rim of the nightmare. The killing had begun. SOUND: The HOWL of the WEREWOLF - distant, a bit dreamy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a.) VIRGIL CUTTS, owner of Virgil's Texaco, is filling up car. We hear the HOWl... and VIRGIL looks up uneasily. b.) In the barber shop, BILLY McCLAREN, the barber, is ju taking the apron off the Methodist minister, REV. O'BANIO They both look around. c.) Folks are coming out of the Gem Theater. They pause a the sound of that HOWL and look toward the edge of town.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE SETTING MOON, CU NIGHT
dialogues.text: As JANE speaks, we see the moon sink below the horizon. JANE (v-o) The killing had begun, but at first no one knew it. Arnie Westrum was a chronic drunk, and what happened seemed like an accident.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE RAIL-RIDER AND ARNIE'S HEADLESS BODY NIGHT
dialogues.text: Slowly the view improves, grows lighter, as we TIME-LAPSE DAWN. SOUND: A train is approaching. We hear its horn. CAMERA MOVES IN. Here is a shattered Rheingold bottle. Th is a litter of ARNIE'S tools. And here, on the cheek of ARNIE'S severed head, a few ants are checking things out. SOUND: The train's horn, MUCH CLOSER. JANE (v-o) The county coroner concluded that Arnie passed out on the tracks. There wasn't enough evidence to conclude anything else. And suddenly the train comes smashing into the frame, hor blaring. The rail-rider goes flying. ARNIE'S body disappe underneath. We see something flopping and moving under there. It could be a bundle of rags. Could be... but isn'

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TARKER'S MILLS TOWN COMMON DAY
dialogues.text: The common is more or less in the center of town, either surrounded by Main Street commerce or backed by it. THE CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY IN on a big tent that's been erected the Common - looks like a revival meeting tent, almost, b the banner draped over the entrance reads: SUPPORT THE

dialogues.speaker: TARKER'S MILLS MEDCU DRIVE
dialogues.text: Behind or to the side, on the grass, picnic tables have b set out end-to-end. Women are putting salads and home-bak breads on these - just about the whole town is going to s down to a meal when the meeting's over. Further off, men tending barbecues, roasting corn, etc. JOE HALLER (amplified voice) I'd like to give you Father Lester Lowe, of Holy Family Catholic Church! Enthusiastic applause greets this.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE CROWD DAY
dialogues.text: Most of the town is here, seated on folding chairs. We're looking particularly at three people - NAN COSLAW, her husband BOB, and their fourteen-year-old daughter, JANE. is JANE - a slightly older JANE - who we have heard speaking. She is now a bit bored with the meeting, which been going on for some time. As the APPLAUSE CONTINUES, s leans toward her mother.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'm going out for a while, 'kay?

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: All right. Stay close. And make sure your brother's all right. As JANE gets up, the applause starts to fade a bit. NOTE: JANE is wearing a silver crucifix, and will continu to wear it through the whole movie.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE PODIUM DAY
dialogues.text: To one side is a big black-and-white photograph on an eas It shows a van which has been customized into an emergenc medical unit. Behind the podium are four chairs. REV. TOM O'BANION sits one of them. ANDY FAIRTON sits in another, red-faced and beaming. JOE HALLER, the town constable, is just returnin to his; LESTER LOWE is just approaching the mike as the applause dies. LOWE'S face shines with love and goodwill.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: For the last ten years... No amplification. He taps the mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is making her way down the row to the aisle (the peop should be seated in folding chairs). She passes a GIRL of about her own age who has overheard NAN'S parting shot. GIRL (mocking) "Make sure your brother's all right." JANE (low) Marty's a booger. She reaches the aisle and starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He taps the mike again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB (good-natured) Just pretend you're in your own church askin' for money, father! It'll work fine! Good-natured laughter greets this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit flustered, he taps the mike and is rewarded by a BR SCREAM OF FEEDBACK.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: For the last ten years, I have had a dream. A dream of a time when modern medical care would come to this small community, which sometimes seems so far from Durham, with her lifesaving hospitals. I hope that this meeting, at which I see so many of my friends gathered, will be the start of making my dream come true. SOUND: Enthusiastic applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a blacksnake... harmless, but big. It goes wriggling through the grass toward a stream. In the b.g. - SOUND OF APPLAUSE. MARTY (voice) Holy...! Brady, are you sure they're not poisonous? BRADY (voice) Little old blacksnake? Hell, no! Hands - the rather grimy hands of a boy bent on mischief grab the blacksnake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRADY holds the snake up. Both boys gaze at it with respectful wonder. NOTE: MARTY is wearing a silver St. Cristopher's medallio and will through the whole movie.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Lemme hold him! BRADY hands it over. As MARTY looks at the snake, BRADY sees:

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JANE, COMING OUT OF THE TENT DAY
dialogues.text: JANE (v-o) I was almost fifteen that summer. My brother Marty was eleven. Marty and his friend Brady Kincaid were the crosses I had to bear. Brady was actually the worse of the two, but I was rarely disposed to see that. Not when my younger brother was so constantly thrown in my face by my parents. LOWE (v-o from the tent) $32,000 is a lot of money. But when you think of the lives this unit might save, it seems very inexpensive indeed. Applause greets this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again we are fairly tight on the boys - we see them from waist or chest height. BRADY snatches back the snake.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: I got an idea.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What? BRADY looks toward JANE. MARTY follows his gaze. His eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You wouldn't. BRADY grins. MARTY assesses the grin.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: You would.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: An endeavor like this seems to me to be the very definition of community - all of us pulling together as one, farmers and merchants... Protestants and Catholics...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is walking slowly toward the picnic area, and is pass under a tree. There's more applause from the tent. BRADY (teasing voice) Jane... Jane... She looks up. The blacksnake dangles down toward her, alm touching her upturned face. JANE shrieks and bolts. She gets a little way, trips over her own feet and falls down hard. She's wearing what was nice jumper and nylons. Now the jumper is torn and the ho shredded at the knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lying over a limb with the snake in his hand, laughi wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up, looks at her clothes, her bloody knees. She' near tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot's from the chest up. He looks sorry he was a par of this little stunt, as he ought to be.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: It was just a blacksnake, Jane-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks around at him in a fury of embarrassment and something very close to hate.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Look at my knees! Look at my dress! I hate you!

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Did wittle Janie make wee-wee in her teddies?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Stop it, Brady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws the snake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dodges the snake with a little scream. She's beginnin to cry, but she flips BRADY the bird just the same.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Ooooh, naughty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves toward JANE - there is something queerly unnatur in this movement, and in a moment we'll understand, but f the time being we must be puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Jane, I'm sorry. It was just a joke. We didn't mean- He's reached her. JANE is sobbing now, hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, no! You never mean to! I hate you, you booger! She runs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swings down and comes over to MARTY. BRADY (with satisfaction) Really got her goat that time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in a wheelchair, looking glumly after JANE.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up, Brady. You're warped.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NEAR THE BANDSTAND, FEATURING JANE DAY
dialogues.text: She's walking slowly along, still crying a little. Now sh steps behind some bushes, looks around, hikes up the skir of her jumper, and wriggles out of the wrecked panty hose STELLA RANDOLPH (voice) Wait! Don't go! Startled, JANE looks around, instinctively yanking her dr down. No one in sight. MAN (voice; rough) Just leave me alone! Now she looks toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man who looks like he might be a traveling salesman who has just stepped whole and breathing from a dirty joke ab the farmer's daughter comes striding down from the bandstand. STELLA RANDOLPH, a plump but sweetly pretty girl, comes t the stairs but does not descend them. She is also crying but these are real tears, folks. STELLA is a human Niagar Falls. STELLA (calls) Please! You have to help me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DECEIVER (keeps walking) It's your oven, but it ain't my bun you're baking in there. Sorry, babe. B.g. SOUNDS: More applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can hear STELLA sobbing as JANE walks slowly toward th bandstand with her panty hose still balled up in one hand JANE looks suddenly aware that she's not the only one in this sad world who has troubles. She reaches the foot of stairs going up to the bandstand and tosses the hose absently in a litter can. JANE mounts the steps timidly.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Stella? Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STELLA has retreated to one of the benches, where she is bawling into a handful of Kleenex. Pudgy and twenty-two, is both funny and terribly sad. She looks around at the sound of JANE's voice. STELLA (alarmed) Who - ? JANE (approaching closer) It's Jane, Stella. Jane Coslaw. STELLA sees it is, and turns away from her, still weeping JANE stands, uncertain what to do next. After a moment sh approaches closer and touches STELLA'S turned back timidl JANE (tenderly) What's wrong? STELLA (weeping) He's going away. I know he is.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Who's going away? STELLA turns to her, weeping still and distracted.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: What am I going to tell my mother? If he won't marry me, what am I going to tell my mother? JANE (bewildered) Stella, I don't know what-

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Oh, leave me alone! Just leave me alone, you stupid thing! STELLA lumbers across the bandstand and down the steps. J stares after her, bewildered and perhaps even a little frightened.

dialogues.speaker: O'BANION
dialogues.text: Let us pray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of them bow their heads.

dialogues.speaker: O'BANION
dialogues.text: May the Grace of God shine upon those gathered here... and lift them up... and grant success to the endeavor to which they have so openheartedly declared their support. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They raise their heads. Some echo the "Amen." Others cros themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are coming out and getting ready to chow-down.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE COSLAW STATION WAGON DAY
dialogues.text: Traveling along a country road. Headed home.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE STATION WAGON DAY
dialogues.text: BOB and NAN COSLAW are sitting up front. MARTY and JANE a in the backseat. JANE is as far from MARTY as she can get She's still mad as hell. Band-Aids crisscross her knees. MARTY'S wheelchair is collapsed in the cargo area of the wagon. NAN turns around to look at the kids - and it's really JA she's mad at.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: I want you two to bury the hatchet. You're being very silly, Jane. JANE (hot) Did you see my knees?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Jane, I-

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: I think you're being mean as well as silly. Your brother has never had a scraped knee in his whole life. Well, here it is - the chief source of JANE'S animus agai her brother and the source of most of the tension in the COSLAW family. MARTY winces and turns away a little, embarrassed - this always happens. He doesn't like it, but he doesn't know h to make his parents - his mother in particular - quit it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You always take his side because he's a cripple! Well, it's not my fault that he's a cripple!

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Come on, Jane- it was Brady's idea. I couldn't stop him.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Brady's a booger and so are you!

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: Jane Coslaw! BOB (roars) Stop it or I'll throw the whole bunch of you out! In this traditional family unit, BOB is the Voice of Authority. They all heed, although the atmosphere remains thundery.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE STATION WAGON DAY
dialogues.text: Train tracks run near the road.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE STATION WAGON, ENSEMBLE DAY
dialogues.text: BOB (points) That's where poor old Arnie Westrum pitched his last drunk. He crosses himself and they all look toward: EXT.  THE GS&WM RAILROAD TRACKS (STATION WAGON'S POV)

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: They had to pick up what was left of him in a peach basket.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, Daddy! Gross!

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Did he really get his head cut off, Dad? That's what Brady said.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: If you don't stop it I'm going to vomit. I mean it. NAN (no sympathy) You're not going to vomit, Jane. And I think we've all had quite enough of this horror-movie talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craning back to look at the spot where ARNIE bit the dust His face is thoughtful, solemn.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE COSLAW HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: JANE is lying in bed, her face to the wall. Dim light fal on her unhappy face as the door is opened. MARTY (v-o) Janey?... Are you awake? JANE says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE DOOR TO JANE'S BEDROOM, WITH MARTY NIGHT
dialogues.text: He is in his "house wheelchair" - not the Silver Bullet ( was in the Bullet during the Common scene, but we didn't a very good look at it). He has some stuff on his lap. A box, for sure.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes are open but she says nothing. Just looks at the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rolls across to her bed and puts something on her nigh table. SOUND of change and a rattle of paper. She rolls o and sees he's put about three bucks on the table. Plus a of mixed nuts.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What's the money for?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: A new pair of panty hose. Is it enough?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I don't want your money. You're a booger.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: It was Brady's idea, Jane. Honest to God. Please take the money. I want to make up. She looks at him and sees he's sincere - honestly contrit She softens. There's hope for these two kids yet, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I can get a pair of L'Eggs down at the pharmacy for a dollar forty-nine. Here. She pushes the rest back to him, then looks at the can. S picks it up, curious.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: That's for you, too. Uncle Al gave it to me- JANE (scorn) That drunk!

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: -but I want you to have it. He gives her a warm, melting smile. When your little brot is being good to you it's time to watch out - but JANE ha been lulled. She starts to open it, then looks questionin at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah, go ahead. She opens it. A long paper snake - the kind with a spring inside it - leaps out. She shrieks.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You booger! MARTY backs up the wheelchair so he's out of her reach. MARTY (grinning) It really is for your birthday, though - try it on Brady. He'll wet his pants.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Go to hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY (smiling) I love you, Janey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to be angry with him... and cannot (this is a response, we'll find, that both MARTY and his UNCLE AL evoke). She smiles at him a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reverses his wheelchair, also smiling a little, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TARKER'S MILLS, UNDER THE MOON NIGHT
dialogues.text: We're looking down at a brave little nestle of lights. SOUND: A HOWL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one light on upstairs and another downstairs... a downstairs is the bluish flicker of TV light. An ivy trellis climbs one side of the house. SOUNDS: Canned laughter; TV dialogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STELLA'S MOTHER, asleep in front of the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A whole bunch of capsules are dumped into it. THE CAMERA DRAWS BACK to show us STELLA, sitting by her vanity mirror. The rest of the room is reflected in the mirror, including the window - we are upstairs. [NOTE: It would be nice to see that fat moon floating in window!] There's a framed picture of STELLA's ex-boyfriend on the vanity beside the dish of pills. STELLA sets down the emp prescription bottle the pills came from beside this pictu We can clearly read the word "Nembutol" on it. There is a a large glass of water on the vanity table. STELLA turns the picture facedown. She might be crying bu probably she's not. She takes about five of the pills, starts to lift them to her mouth- A HOWL outside... closer. STELLA looks around for a moment, then takes the pills wi some water. She pauses, looking at herself.

dialogues.speaker: STELLA
dialogues.text: Suicides go to hell. Especially if they're pregnant. And I don't even care. She takes another five pills. And another five. SOUNDS: Rattling foliage.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE IVY TRELLIS NIGHT
dialogues.text: Claw-hands are seizing it and climbing. SOUNDS of hoarse, guttural breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes another handful of pills... and the window behi her shatters inward. There is a bellowing roar as the werewolf throws itself through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits up, startled awake. From upstairs: ANOTHER SHATTERING ROAR... FOLLOWED BY A SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs... and a huge claw-hand rips through the back of her nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Oh my dear God... Stella! She runs for the doorway and the hall. From upstairs come confusion of SOUNDS: roars, breaking furniture, shatterin glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of those deadly claw-hands sweeps down the bed, rippi through the sheets... the mattress... the spring itself. Hairy, muddy feet with protruding talons leap onto it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The werewolf leaps out - it's graceful, savage, animal. SOUND: A TRIUMPHANT HOWL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's found an ancient pistol somewhere and is lugging it gamely along.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Stella!...Stella! She reaches the closed door of STELLA's room, vacillates there for a moment... and then pushes it open and goes in A long beat of silence as we hold on the door. MOTHER SHRIEKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shrieks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a total shambles; blood is splattered everywhere; th mirror is broken, the picture of DAN the gay deceiver is broken; the bed is torn in two. There are big, muddy wolfprints on the remnants of the bed. STELLA lies propped in the corner with Nembutols all arou her. Suicide may have been what she planned, but it sure isn't what happened. MOTHER SHRIEKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a.) MR. PELTZER puts out his paper rack - just the "Press-Herald" this morning. He looks shocked and grim. T scare headline: BRUTAL MURDER ROCKS WESTERN MAINE. We can see STELLA'S photograph. b.) Through the window of Robertson's Luncheonette, we se the proprietor, BOBBY ROBERTSON, talking earnestly with a bunch of men. Among them: MILT STURMFULLER, ALFIE KNOPFLE VIRGIL CUTTS, BILLY McCLAREN, and ELMER ZINNEMAN, a farme we'll meet later. c.) At Andy's Sporting Goods, ANDY FAIRTON is putting a b hand-lettered sign in the window. It reads: REMINGTON

dialogues.speaker: AND YOUR FAMILY
dialogues.text: d.) At the Methodist parsonage, a '53 Dodge pulls slowly and MOTHER RANDOLPH gets out, weeping. As she approaches parsonage door, LESTER LOWE comes out and embraces her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sign reads: TARKER'S MILLS TOWN OFFICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neatly lettered on the panel: TARKER'S MILLS CONSTABULARY And below this: JOSEPH HALLER. JOE HALLER (voice) Okay...yes...Oh, fuck off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HALLER slams the phone down with an angry bang. He looks like a guy who has been up all night. PETE, his pudgy deputy, looks like a high school athlete who has suddenly found himself batting in the World Series.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What'd they say, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: They said they'd be here by noon. PETE (nervous) Maybe it wasn't such a good idea telling that Smokey Bear from the Detective Division to fuck off, Joe. HALLER (morosely) I waited until he hung up. Jesus, what a mess. I wish I'd stayed in the army. Let's go on out there. He gets slowly up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TARKER'S MILLS CONSOLIDATED SCHOOL AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: It's a comfortable red-brick building on a side street. I climbs up the sides. Two or three rows of bikes stand alo one side of the building. SOUND: The bell rings. A beat or two, then the doors bang wide and a billion kid spill out. It's the end of the first day of school, and t are excited. They range from Grade 1 to Grade 8. Most kid book it for home as fast as they can, getting on their bi and riding or just running. Everyone has a pink report card.

dialogues.speaker: STURMFULLER
dialogues.text: BRADY and TAMMY are riding bikes. Now there is the SOUND a gasoline engine, and MARTY catches up. He's got the Sil Bullet's motor running for the first time in the movie. Later on it will sound extremely powerful, like a racing car, but now it just sounds like a big lawnmower engine w a muffler on it. It's pretty cool, though - a bright metallic silver with flame decals on the motor housing. Looks sort of like something Big Daddy Roth might have thought up. On the back is a license plate which says SIL BULLET.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Look out! Look out! It's Madman Marty and the Silver Bullet! TAMMY laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: You glad to be back in jail, Marty?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Sure - I like school.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: You booger.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: That's what my sister says, too. Pretty soon I'm going to start checking the mirror to see if I'm turning green.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: I gotta split - see ya, Marty... Tammy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TAMMY and MARTY watch as BRADY zooms off toward home on h bike. MARTY pushes in a hand clutch and moves a small lever. He bumps down over the curb and they cross the street side b side, TAMMY on her bike, MARTY in his wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pops up over the curbing with a bounce. He shoves in t little hand clutch and revs the engine. Va-room!

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Not bad, huh? My Uncle Al took off the regular muffler and put on a Cherry Bomb.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Glasspack. He said he'd come over sometime this summer and we'd soup up the engine... but now I dunno. He's getting a divorce and he's in the doghouse with my mother.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: For getting a divorce?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Well... it is his third.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: The other kids are gone; they are alone. The sidewalk has ended and they roll slowly along the dirt verge of the ro They look toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driveway is blocked off with a sawhorse bearing the stenciled words POLICE INVESTIGATION. The yard is filled with cop cars - HALLER'S constable car, plus a number of state police vehicles. Uniformed men come and go. We can see a large black wreath on the door.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming with me, Marty- I was scared to go past her house by myself. MARTY (matter-of-fact) Yeah... it is a little scary.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: I mean, I saw her. All the time. TAMMY stops her bike. She's on the verge of tears.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: I used to see her every day, and she never knew what was going to happen to her, and neither did I! I mean I know how stupid that sounds, but...

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Hey, take it easy. I know how you feel. He gets the Silver Bullet moving again, and she has to pe along to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop at the end.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: There's something else scary.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What? TAMMY (points) That.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It stands a bit behind the house itself. A creepy place. Many of the glass panes are broken; some of these - not m - have been blocked with cardboard. The inside is a jungl of plants that have run to riot. In the f.g. is a mucky-looking garden patch where nothing much is growing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is quite deeply troubled.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: I've been hearing noises in there.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What kind of noises?

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Rattling. Rustling.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Rats...

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: And my dad says it's kids. But it's not rats and it's not kids. It's-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my suds and body, here is the Great American Alcoholic for sure - the rural version. MILT is wearing a suit of pee-stained thermal underwear. He's wearing a baseball ca with the word "Caterpillar" on the front and has a bottle beer in one hand (I'm pretty sure that his beer is Rheing the dry beer). With his other hand he is busily scratchin his crotch.

dialogues.speaker: MILT
dialogues.text: Tammy, you get on in here and do some dishes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sinister...spooky. TAMMY (voice) I've got to go.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I'd go out and take a look myself, but I think the Bullet'd get stuck in the garden. It looks sorta greasy. She smiles at him, bends over, and kisses him on the mout MARTY is stunned... but happy.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: You would, wouldn't you? MARTY (Joe Cool) Sure. No sweat.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Well, it's probably nothing. I'm just spooked since... you know.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah... but if you hear any more noises, tell your father. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: Okay. Have you got enough gas to get home, Marty? MARTY (Startled) Jeez!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a gas gauge here, and the needle is almost on "E.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I'm always doing this! I gotta go, Tammy. MILT (voice)

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: TAMMY (calls) Coming Daddy! (To MARTY) Bye... thanks again for coming home with me. She waves and goes biking down the driveway as MARTY moto back onto the street and turns toward town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She brings her bike to a stop by her father.

dialogues.speaker: MILT
dialogues.text: 'Bout time. Why you want to hang around that cripple?

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY
dialogues.text: I like him.

dialogues.speaker: MILT
dialogues.text: Goddamn cripples always end up on welfare. Ought to electrocute all of 'em. Balance the fucking budget. Having delivered this pearl of wisdom, MILT goes inside, scratching his ass. TAMMY pauses a moment and looks towar THE CAMERA, her face troubled and scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's buzzing along toward downtown, which is still some distance away - but at least he's made it back to the sidewalk again. MARTY (prayerfully) Come on, baby- He looks down at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the needle is lying all the way over on "E."

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VIRGIL'S TEXACO LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: MARTY pulls in. The wheelchair motor starts to pop and lu and misfire. The chair makes it to the first pump on the island closest to the street and then stalls as VIRGIL CU comes over.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: Well, Marty! I see you lucked out again!

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yep. Would you fill it up, please, Mr. Cutts?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: Want me to check the oil?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Sure!

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: Wipe the windshield an check the driver's bullshit level? MARTY laughs; VIRGIL starts carefully pumping gas into th Silver Bullet's small tank.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE COSLAW HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Overhead is the moon, three days past the full. UNCLE AL (voice) I'll see your Carlton Fiske and raise you a George Brett... a Dave Kingman... and a Rod Carew.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE KITCHEN DOORWAY, WITH NAN COSLAW NIGHT
dialogues.text: She's wiping her hands with a dishtowel and looks like sh just bit into a lemon.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE DEN, WITH UNCLE AL AND MARTY NIGHT
dialogues.text: UNCLE AL is the family's sheep of a darker color. He's thirty, good-looking, raffish. He's also drunk. He's got both whiskey and beer. An ashtray beside him overflows wi butts. He and MARTY are playing draw poker for MARTY'S baseball cards. Each has a pile in front of him. MARTY really loves UNCLE AL... his eyes just glow when he looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. I call. He tosses in three baseball cards.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, wait a minute! He grabs one of MARTY'S cards, looks at it, and tosses it back.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Ralph Houk! You can't bet a manager! Stone the crows!

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. Dwight Evans.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Piss on him. Piss on all the Red Sox. He swallows whiskey and chases it with beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NAN comes briskly over. She's seen and heard enough. She favors UNCLE AL with a glare and then looks protectively MARTY.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: Come on, Marty- bedtime. She starts to wheel him away.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Mom-!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Let the boy finish the game, Nan. He means it, drunk or not. She reluctantly rolls MARTY ba to the table.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: Make it quick. UNCLE AL lays down his hand.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Three kings. MARTY (delighted) I got a straight to the queen!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Bullshit luck! NAN (outraged) That's enough! MARTY (as his mother wheels him away) Aww, Mom-!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY is sitting in a stair chair that rises slowly to th second floor. He looks dejected and glum. SOUND of NAN hectoring her brother AL. I don't think we c make out all of what's going on, but we've all known wome like NAN and I think we can fill in the blanks. "Christia household... you come here drunk and expect... can't even bother to call ahead..." Etc., etc. A wheelchair stands on the second-floor landing. This one no Silver Bullet, only the more humble sort that moves by arm power. When the stair chair clicks to a stop, MARTY hoists himself from it into the wheelchair and rolls down the hall toward the bathroom. Below, NAN'S rant is still going on.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE DEN, WITH NAN AND UNCLE AL NIGHT
dialogues.text: UNCLE AL is clearing up in a kind of drunken stupor- and mean he is really drunk. He's smoking one cigarette; anot is smoldering away in the heaping ashtray. He drops a pil of baseball cards on the floor and bonks his head on the table bending down to pick them up.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: I don't want you drinking around Marty. That's too much. If you can't stop it, you better stay away. AL straightens up. There is a sort of command force in th man, and here he is partly able to rise above his abysmal drunkenness so we can see it.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: I come here because Marty needs a friend.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: Yes... you've always been that to him. But if you can't leave your booze in whatever dump you call home, you better just stay away. She leaves the room, almost crying. UNCLE AL looks after her, and then his attention is drawn to the smoldering ashtray. He pours beer over the mess, putting out the fir but creating something that looks even worse. He begins drunkenly picking up again. UNCLE AL (to himself) Another wonderful time at Sister Nan's house! Heeyyy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY, now in pj's, is brushing his teeth. JANE comes in- she's wearing a nightie.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Mom was really mad at him this time, wasn't she?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What do you expect, when he comes in smelling like a brewery and looking like an unmade bed?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Stop it! He lunges at her, but JANE steps back easily. MARTY overbalances and falls out of the wheelchair. His toothbr clatters across the tile. BOB COSLAW (sleepy voice) Hey! That you, Marty?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: He's okay, Dad! She looks around swiftly, then bends down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of MARTY'S cheeks is pressed against the floor. His e are shut. He's weeping. JANE (low) Marty, are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yes. Go away.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Let me help you up. NAN (voice) Marty? SOUND of her climbing the stairs. JANE throws a quick look back over her shoulder and then helps MARTY up in his chair. He helps by pulling on the s counter. JANE has time to give MARTY one quick look- "Ple don't tell on me," it says. NAN comes in.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: Jane, have you been teasing your brother again?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: She wasn't, Mom- I dropped my toothbrush and fell over when I tried to get it. Jane helped pick me up. He bats his eyes at her. MARTY (syrupy voice) Jane's wunnnderful. JANE picks up his toothbrush. JANE (hands it to him) Here. Brush them good, Marty. Some of that shit in your head might leak down into your mouth and poison you.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: Jane Coslaw! But JANE stalks off. MARTY is grinning. It was a good put-down.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE STURMFULLER HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: We can see the moon in the sky beyond the ruined greenhou THE CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY TOWARD the greenhouse. We begin t pick up SOUNDS: RATTLING...RUSTLING...and low animal GRUN

dialogues.speaker: INT. TAMMY'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: She's deeply asleep.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE LIVING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: "Big-time Wrestling" on the TV. SOUND of a refrigerator d closing. MILT STURMFULLER comes into the living room from the kitchen. He's wearing his long johns with the designe pee stains and has a quart bottle of Rheingold the dry be in each hand. He sits down, looking at the TV. MILT (drunk) Give him the airplane! Wring his neck!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE GREENHOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: More noises. There is a beat of silence, and then somethi one of those earthen plant pots, I think- falls over and SHATTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up briefly- he's heard something- but the crowd the TV is loud and the match is reaching its climax. MILT (all eyes again) Give him the sleeper, you fuckin bugwit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LOW SNARL. Plants shake and shiver. Another crash, LOUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks toward the window. He gets up, goes over, and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND of another crash. Plants move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a shotgun from the wall, breaks it, and looks inside.

dialogues.speaker: MILT
dialogues.text: Let's see if you want to come back and break my pots all to shit after I put some rock salt in your asses!

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE STURMFULLER GREENHOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: The door at the end SCREECHES OPEN and MILT, still holdin the shotgun at port arms, comes cautiously in. This place really overgrown. MILT advances slowly into the jungle of plants, and the director will shoot it as he likes to build the suspense. I'm sure that plants brush his face, and a bug or two- ma even a big plump spider- will land on him. He hears a SCUTTERING SOUND and whirls. MILT (shouts) Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mouse goes running across the warped boards (which have pulled apart from each other, showing deep cracks between

dialogues.speaker: INT. MILT NIGHT
dialogues.text: He relaxes and starts forward again. We keep expecting it happen, but it keeps not happening. Then, as MILT is starting back toward the door, two big, hairy arms come up through the floor- bursting through tw of those cracks and shoving the splintered boards upward- and grab MILT'S legs at the knees. SOUNDS: BESTIAL ROARS. MILT screams and triggers off the shotgun- unfortunately, is pointing straight up. Glass showers down on him. He is pulled down into the shattered hole- now we can see him o from the knees up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits up in bed. SOUNDS of ROARS and MILT SCREAMING from the greenhouse. MRS. STURMFULLER, in a nightgown with her hair done up in rollers, comes into Tammy's room.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STURMFULLER
dialogues.text: Tammy, where's your father? SOUND: Another SCREAM from the greenhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's now waist deep in the hole in the floor, surrounded broken, splintered boards. SOUNDS: RIPPING FLESH, CRUNCHING BONES. MILT SHRIEKS. He is abruptly jerked downward again. He is being eaten f the feet up. As he's jerked down, one of the leaning, splintered boards rams into his chest. MILT collapses ove it like an old Roman collapsing on his sword. A hairy arm reaches up and grabs his neck. MILT is jerked all the way into the hole, board and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUNDS of SNARLS, GROWLS, GRUNTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are hugging each other, terrified, by the window.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE STURMFULLER PLACE, MEDIUM-LONG DAY
dialogues.text: The police cars are now here. There's also a meat wagon. we watch, a number of cops- JOE HALLER and PETE SYLVESTER are among them- approach the wagon. Many are carrying can bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops the blood stained bag he's carrying, runs to the bushes, and noisily blows his groceries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a.) On Oak Street, MRS. THAYER is hurrying toward home, obviously spooked. She keeps looking behind herself and nearly flies up the steps to her house. Then there is the endless business of fumbling with her keys. Finally she lurches inside and slams the door. b.) On Main Street, at the Holy Family rectory, FATHER O'BANION is closing the shutters...and locking them. c.) On a residential street, a kid is playing with some plastic trucks outside of a picket fence. Except for him, the street is deserted. His mother comes out and hauls hi in. d.) ANDY FAIRTON, in the sporting-goods store, checks an automatic pistol and then holsters it on his hip. He has pugnacious, unpleasant look. e.) BILLY McCLAREN turns the sign on the door of his barb shop from OPEN to CLOSED, looks out warily at the street make sure there are no psycho killers out there for trims guess), then leaves and locks the door behind him. THE CAMERA FOLLOWS him down a couple of store fronts to Owen' where he also goes in. f.) The paper rack in front of Peltzer's Drug/ The "Press-Herald" headline is a sixteen-pointer: MANIAC CLAI SECOND VICTIM.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARTY AND BRADY KINCAID MAGIC HOUR
dialogues.text: They're flying kites on the common. Some distance in the b.g. is the bandstand. MARTY is of course flying his kite he sits in the Silver Bullet. The boys are having a blast THE CAMERA SLOWLY MOVES AWAY from the boys, centers on Owen's Pub across the street, and ZOOMS IN. In the window is a poster. It reads: $10,000 REWARD FOR

dialogues.speaker: INFORMATION LEADING TO THE CAPTURE OF THE MAN, (OR ANIMAL)
dialogues.text: WHO KILLED STELLA RANDOLPH AND MILTON STURMFULLER. And, a the bottom: TARKER'S MILLS CITIZENS' COMMITTEE. Along comes ANDY FAIRTON. He goes into the pub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a f.g. table: VIRGIL CUTTS, BOBBY ROBERTSON, ELMER ZINNEMAN, and his brother PORTER ZINNEMAN. Behind them, a the bar, we see PETE SYLVESTER having a beer with BILLY McCLAREN. As we look around the bar, we will also see FAT LESTER LOWE, sitting at an unobtrusive corner table, nurs a beer and listening closely to the conversation. ELMER (to VIRGIL) Don't tell me an animal can't rip a man up the way Milt Sturmfuller was ripped up!

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: But the woman's bed was ripped right down the middle, Elmer- it's take a chainsaw to do something like that!

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Damn straight!

dialogues.speaker: ELMER
dialogues.text: Shut up, Porter. (To VIRGIL) What about the tracks? ANDY FAIRTON has joined the group. He sits down uninvited

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: That could be something to throw off the cops. And it ain't animals that try to confues the law; it's people do that.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY FAIRTON
dialogues.text: Law around here don't need much confusing. PETE looks around at this. Being the deputy constable and ineffectual by nature, he's pretty sensitive. ANDY (deep disgust) Joe Haller couldn't find his own ass if someone rammed it full of radium and gave him a Geiger counter. PETE SYLVESTER (comes over) Could be I know a fella who's still PO'd over getting fined two hundred bucks for that little fender bender out on the Ridge Road last year.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Could be I know a fat old fella who ought to take care of his mouth before someone comes along and turns it inside out. I pay Joe Haller's salary to keep the people in this town safe, and he ain't doing it. INT.  BILLY McCLAREN, AT THE BAR He's looking toward the table where the Fairton group sit BILLY (mildly) Last town report said you was in arrears your taxes, Andy. Guess you must have paid up, huh?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: What are you, trying to be smart? OWEN KNOPFLER comes over.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: You guys turn down the thermostat or I'm gonna turn you all out. Now who's drinking? ANDY (sulks) Bring me a Schlitz.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A TREE, WITH BRADY'S SMILE-KITE STUCK IN IT DUSK
dialogues.text: SOUND of panting. MARTY comes into the frame, pulling himself up by the arm His arms are very strong, although his legs trail limply behind him (like the tail of a kite). He sits on a branch untangles the kite and the string, and looks down. MARTY (calls) Here it comes!

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: Drop it! As the kite flutters down, JANE comes biking up.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Marty Coslaw, you get down out of that tree!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He descends, then hangs from the lowest branch.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Push the Bullet over, Jane, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE (makes no immediate move to do so) Supper was an hour ago, Dumbo. MARTY (hanging) Oh, Jeez! I forgot! Is she mad?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: They both are. At me, for not getting you sooner. I ought to let you fall. But she pushes the chair over and MARTY drops into it. He pushes the starter and the Silver Bullet fires up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BRADY, FLYING HIS KITE ON THE COMMON DUSK
dialogues.text: MARTY (voice) Hey, Brady! You coming? BRADY (looking into the sky) In a while! BRADY could give a shit if MARTY'S in trouble. He just wa vaguely. He's into the kite-flying experience, as the fol in Marin County might say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's looking toward the common, frowning and uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Come on, Marty. She starts biking away. MARTY starts after her, pauses, a looks at:

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BRADY, ON THE COMMON DUSK
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS SLOWLY UP to the yellow smile-kite in the bluish-purple sky.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OWEN'S PUB LATE DUSK
dialogues.text: The former patrons are still here, with the exceptions of LOWE, BILLY McCLAREN, and BOBBY ROBERTSON. Many others ha appeared; this is Happy Hour. Among them we see MR. ASPINALL, the principal, and PELTZER, the druggist. A barmaid, NORMA, circulates with drinks and beers. Speaking of beer, ANDY FAIRTON has gotten through a fair amount of Schlitz. It hasn't mellowed him, however; he's more belligerent than ever. ANDY (holding forth) This whole investigation has been as efficient as a Polish fire drill! It- PETE (bravely) I've heard enough out of you, Andy. If you don't shut your mouth, I'm going to shut it for you.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE DOOR OF OWEN'S PLACE
dialogues.text: It opens and a man in a business suit- HERB KINCAID- come in. He is carrying a briefcase and he looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDY (astounded) What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Jesus wept. He reaches under the bar and comes out with a baseball ba Burned into the side of the bat, so it reads vertically toward the handle, is the word "peacemaker." OWEN hurries around the bar with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETE is standing in front of ANDY, fists balled up, fat f trembling with determination.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You heard what I said, motormouth. ANDY gets up, infuriated. There's apparently going to be brawl. Behind them, HERB KINCAID has approached the table HERB hasn't even noticed what's going on; he's got proble of his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clears his throat. This is a mild, timid man- he doesn like to speak in public, particularly not in a bar, but t imperatives of the situation demand it right now. HERB (quite loudly) Has anyone in here seen my son Brady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks at HERB. Conversation stops. ANDY and PETE freeze with their fists balled up, like little kids playi statues tag. OWEN is caught a little distance from ANDY a PETE, with the "peacemaker" still in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it is almost completely dark, and a large reddish sum moon is rising over the horizon. SOUND: A LONG, WAVERING WOLF HOWL... LOUD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All conversation has stopped. All have turned toward the door and the windows; all hear the HOWL. Deep fright overlies each face. NORMA drops her tray. Glasses and bottles shatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE HALLER comes out of the constable's office in a hurry letting the door bang the wall. He's buckling on his gun belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRADY'S kite, torn in a couple of places, flutters on the steps leading up to the bandstand. The yellow smile face grins eerily in the darkness. It is streaked with blood.

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: Brady! He breaks for the door. ANDY FAIRTON grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: Get out of my way! He pushes ANDY aside. HERB is out the door, chased by PET and several of the others.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE BANDSTAND NIGHT
dialogues.text: JOE HALLER (low voice) Hail Mary, full of grace, the Lord is with thee. Blessed art thou among women... He comes out of the shadows, his drawn gun dangling by hi side. This man has had an extremely bad shock. The legs o his uniform pants are splashed with blood. He makes it do two steps and then sits heavily by the remains of BRADY'S smiling, bloody kite. He looks straight ahead. He looks a nothing. HALLER (low) ...and blessed is the fruit of Thy womb. Jesus. Holy Mary, Mother of God, pray for us sinners now...now... He looks at the kite, then looks away. He puts a hand ove his face and starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE COMMON, LOOKING BACK TOWARD MAIN STREET NIGHT
dialogues.text: A number of men - not all that were in Owen's but quite a few of them - are running toward the bandstand. HERB KINC is in the lead, screaming his son's name over and over. SOUND: A LONG HOWL, now at some distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As HERB KINCAID approaches.

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: Stay off the bandstand, Herb.

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: Is it my boy? Is it Brady?

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: Don't go up- HERB (lunges past him) Brady! Brady! Disappears into the dark. HALLER looks down at his lap.

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: Br-(CUTS OFF) The other men arrive, PETE in the lead. HALLER doesn't lo up.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Joe, is it- HALLER (not looking up) Shhh.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Is it the Kicaid b- HALLER (not looking up) Shhh, I said. The men look uneasily at HALLER, at each other. ANDY FAIR shoves forward.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: What the fuck is going on h- SOUND: HERB SCREAMS. A pause. HERB screams again. The men flinch back. HALLER doesn't look up. Now, from the darkne on the bandstand, HERB begins to LAUGH. The men shrink ba further, looking more uneasy than ever. HERB (voice; laughing) We'll bury his shoes. Now HALLER gets up and joins the other men. HERB (voice; laughing) That's what we'll have to do; we'll bury his shoes. Maybe in a couple of Roi-Tan cigar boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HERB KINCAID appears. He is laughing. He is smeared with son's blood. In each hand he holds one of his son's shoes

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: We'll bury his shoes because his feet are still in them and they're the only part of him that makes sense anymore. HERB laughs harder.

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: It's gonna be the cheapest funeral this town ever saw!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOLY FAMILY CHURCH DAY
dialogues.text: SOUND: An organ is playing that sweet old hymn, "Bringing The Sheaves." There are lots of cars parked in front of the church, but there's a space left just big enough for UNCLE AL'S MG. MARTY'S Silver Bullet is strapped to the back. JANE (v-o) My mother and father- my mother in particular- did not much care for Uncle Al...

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOLY FAMILY CHURCH DAY
dialogues.text: MARTY'S chair is at the back of the church. Most of the mourners are crying. MRS. BOWIE is playing the organ. BRADY'S coffin is on a bier at the front - closed of cour There are lots of flowers. JANE (v-o continues) ...but when it came to such unpleasant duties as taking Marty to the funeral of his best friend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we look at them, from left to right: UNCLE AL, MARTY, TAMMY, MRS. STURMFULLER. UNCLE AL unobtrusively takes a small silver flask from hi hip pocket. Engraved on it in Old English letters is the word "rotgut." He spins the cap and takes a quick knock. pauses and glances at MARTY, who looks deeply stunned. JANE (v-o continues) ...they didn't at all mind drafting him. As to the sort of comfort Uncle Al may have been able to offer him... UNCLE AL hands the flask to MARTY. MARTY looks at him questioningly for a moment, and then drinks. MARTY looks TAMMY, who looks frankly terrible. Her mother is looking away. MARTY nudges her. She looks around at him. He offer her the flask. Her eyes widen. JANE (v-o continues) ...I now believe that was best kept between the two of them... After a brief moment's consideration, TAMMY takes the fla and has a deep swallow. She hands the flask back to MARTY who hands it quickly back to UNCLE AL as TAMMY coughs. He mother looks at her... then at MARTY and UNCLE AL. UNCLE smiles sympathetically, hiding the flask with one hand, a if to say, "Isn't it a terrible thing?" MRS. STURMFULLER looks distractedly back toward the service. JANE (v-o concludes) ...or among the three of them. UNCLE AL pockets the flask just as the organ stops playin

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Kincaid have asked that there be no mass said here this afternoon. There will be a requiem mass for Brady Kincaid this Sunday. They did ask me to say a word of comfort to you, if I could. He looks out at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look back at LOWE, hoping for some help in understanding this awful thing.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: If there is any word of comfort I can give you, it's just this: the face of the beast always becomes known; the time of the beast always passes. He is struggling with this, trying dreadfully hard.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: If there are times when we feel alone and afraid, only small creatures in the dark, then these are the times when we must turn to one another for our comfort and our hope. To our neighbors. To our community. To our love for each other. I alone cannot ease the pain for Herb and Naomi Kincaid, nor can I ease your pain, nor you ease mine. But if I believe anything it's this: we can comfort each other. We can heal each other. We can go on together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids are crying. MARTY puts an arm around TAMMY and s puts her head on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: The Bible tells us not to fear the terror that creepeth by night or that which flieth by noonday, and yet we do... we do. Because there is much we don't know, and we feel very small. But we must not be alone. We must not allow ourselves to be alone, for there is the wide gate to the hell of terror. Turn to each other. Join hands in your sorrow and try to remember that the face of the beast always becomes known. (Pause) The time of the beast always passes. (Pause) Let us pray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY and TAMMY look at each other miserably. TAMMY begin to cry- for her father as much as for BRADY, one would think- and she and MARTY embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the kids with deep sympathy and deep love.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A COUNTRY ROAD AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: UNCLE AL'S sports car passes THE CAMERA. He's taking MART home.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: You all right, Marty?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: There's a saying- so-and-so was better than a poke in the eye with a sharp stick. You ever hear that one?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not sure that was. Christ! They better get the guy.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Uncle Al, what if it's not a guy?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What if it's some kind of monster? UNCLE AL (laughs) Jesus, Marty! Come off it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It cruises past Owen's Pub. There are cars parked out fro but there are also lots of pickup trucks.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What's going on at Owen's, Uncle Al?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: A bunch of men getting ready to pretend they're Clint Eastwood... Marty, didn't anybody ever tell you that the only monsters are in comic books and drive-in movies?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE COSLAW HOUSE LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: UNCLE AL'S car turns in and parks.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Tammy said she'd been hearing noises in that greenhouse. Growling noises, like a big animal. Her father was killed that night. UNCLE AL looks at him doubtfully for a moment, as if almo believing. Then he shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Marty, you have to get this idea out of your head. Psychotics are more active when the moon is full, and this guy is a psycho. He's going to turn out to be as human as you or me. (Pause) In a manner of speaking. Now let's get you inside. He opens his door and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would like to believe UNCLE AL... but he doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY FAIRTON
dialogues.text: Okay, you all know what group you're in and what area you'll be covering, right?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER ZINNEMAN
dialogues.text: Damn straight!

dialogues.speaker: ELMER ZINNEMAN
dialogues.text: Shut up, Porter. The men are all dressed in hunting clothes- red-and-black-checked shirts, orange caps, etc. They all have guns. Among their number are a few women as well, looking tough and determined. We see almost everyone we'v met up to this point. LOWE is there, looking deeply troubled. ANDY FAIRTON is standing on the bar. These are his vigilantes; he has organized them. ANDY radiates male mac football-coach confidence. He's mesmerized the crowd: the really believe they are going to go out and Shoot One for the Gipper.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Groups one through four are in the woods north of the Sturmfuller place. Five and six west of Carson Creek. The door at the back opens; HALLER and PETE come in. JOE HALLER is in extremely bad shape. He hasn't come back muc from the murder of BRADY. I believe he is having some sor of spiritual crisis, and while it is not our purpose to explore what it might be- this is, after all, a horror mo and not a John Cassavetes film- we can see that it has seriously weakened his authority. ANDY (continuing) Moonrise at 8:52 p.m. Some nervous laughter greets this. Meanwhile, HALLER and PETE are working their way to the front, where they end u next to a grim-faced HERB KINCAID. ANDY (continuing) If he comes out to stroll in the moonlight tonight, we're going to get the sorry sucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PORTER (happily) Damn straight!

dialogues.speaker: ELMER
dialogues.text: Shut up, Porter.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Just remember, it's the psycho we want, not each other. So look before you-

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: I want all of you folks to go home! A disgruntled murmur meets this. HALLER moves forward a b and turns to face them.

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: I can't remember deputizing a single one of you!

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: That's right, Joe- the only deputy you got is that fat shitbag beside you, and neither one of you has done a damn thing about solving this case. There is a mutter of agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDY hops off the bar to face HALLER directly. In the b.g we see HERB KINCAID (KINCAID, by the way, should be weari a black armband- he's come directly from his son's funera HALLER (without much force) We'll catch him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You couldn't catch a cold. HALLER looks at him for a moment, then turns to look at t crowd. They look rather like a lynch mob; on their faces see an uneasy mix of shame and eager determination. HALLE speaks with a kind of haggard, fading desperation.

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: The law has a name for what you men are planning. It's private justice, and private justice is about a step and a half away from lynch mobs and hang ropes. I'm no J. Edgar Hoover, but I am the law in Tarker's Mills, and I want you men to go home. They shuffle their feet uneasily; many look down. He is getting to them.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Don't let this guy scare you! What's he done since this thing started but hang his face out? It's not working. Many of the men look disgusted with bot ANDY and themselves. ANDY (louder) He ain't got so much as a fingerprint!

dialogues.speaker: OWEN KNOPFLER
dialogues.text: Ah, shut up, Andy.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Don't tell me to- HERB KINCAID steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: Yes. Correct. Shut up. ANDY, surprised and bewildered, does. HERB turns and look grimly at JOE HALLER, who can barely meet his gaze. HERB (quietly) I just came from my boy's funeral.

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: Herb...I know how upset- how grief-stricken you must be...but- HERB (quietly) He was torn apart. Utter silence in OWEN'S place now. The others are staring rapt.

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, but- HERB (still quiet) Upset, you say. Grief-stricken, you say. Constable, you don't know what those words mean. My son was torn to pieces. To pieces! HERB turns to the others in the pub. Tears stream down hi face.

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: My son was torn to pieces! (turning back to HALLER) You come in here and talk to these men about private justice. You dare to do that. Constable Haller, why don't you go out to Harmony Hill and dig up what's left of Brady and explain to him about private justice. Would you want to do that? HALLER makes no reply. He looks down at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: No. I thought not. (to the others) You folks stay here if you want. I wouldn't ask anyone to do anything that runs counter to his conscience. As for me... I'm going out and hunt up a little private justice. ANDY FAIRTON has swelled up again. He grins poisonously a the slumped HALLER. He pushes off after HERB KINCAID. Oth men start to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men are streaming out, getting into station wagons and pickup trucks. Engines roar into life. They begin backing out even as more men come out of the pub. We even hear so high-spirited yells; they are on their way and their bloo is up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LESTER LOWE, looking more distressed than ever, pushes hi way through the men toward the door, and THE CAMERA FOLLO He grabs BILLY McCLAREN.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: Billy... Billy, this is a bad idea. Joe can... BILLY (not looking at LOWE) Joe's had his chance, Father. Leave me be. He pushes outside. LOWE looks around wildly; his face say he can't believe this is happening. He grabs PORTER ZINNEMAN, then, as PORTER shoves by him, at a couple of others with mounting desperation. HALLER makes his way to LOWE through the thinning crowd a draws him aside.

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: Let them go.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: But-

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: This is that spirit of community you were talking about. Grand, ain't it? Maybe they'll shoot a hitchhiker or something and Andy can mount the head and raffle it off. To benefit the Medcu van, of course. HALLER laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: But can't we do anything? OWEN KNOPFLER hurries past them; he has a rifle over one shoulder in a sling. In his left hand he carries the peacemaker bat.

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: Sure. We can pray to Christ that none of them get killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More cars and trucks pull away. There's a big old Ford "woody" wagon still there, with ANDY FAIRTON standing impatiently by the driver's side door. BILLY McCLAREN and BOBBY ROBERTSON are with him, and a big, solid-looking wo named MAGGIE ANDREWS. OWEN comes out and crosses to the woody.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Well, it's about frigging time! They'll have his hide tacked to somebody's barn door before we get out there! They pile into the car, ANDY behind the wheel. He throws into gear and backs out onto Main Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a parade of cars and pickup trucks headed out of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's standing on the curb and watching them leave town in procession, some honking their horns, others yelling cheerfully. The expression on his face is dark and broodi

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ELMER AND PORTER ZINNEMAN NIGHT
dialogues.text: ELMER is lying on his belly, stuck halfway under a barbed-wire fence. The seat of his pants is badly snagged The brothers are on the verge of a wooded area. We can se ground mist creeping around the bottoms of the trees.

dialogues.speaker: ELMER
dialogues.text: Help me Porter, goddammit! PORTER grabs ELMER'S right arm and pulls. There's a RIPPI SOUND. ELMER screams.

dialogues.speaker: ELMER
dialogues.text: Don't pull me! You want to rip the right cheek of my ass right off?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Well, Elmer, there are folks that'd say you've been half-assed most of your-

dialogues.speaker: ELMER
dialogues.text: Are you going to unhook me or be a wise guy? PORTER begins to pick the barbed wire out of ELMER'S pant

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: O'BANION looks rather amusing in his hunting gear- like t priest from "The Exorcist" on safari.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: Jesus, that was close. Uh, pardon me, Rev'runt.

dialogues.speaker: O'BANION
dialogues.text: Come on. Be careful. They move slowly ahead, O'BANION still a bit in the lead. THE CAMERA FOLLOWS as the reverend pushes into some knee-high brush. SOUND: A RUSTY METALLIC CLANG, followed by a FLESHY CHOMP O'BANION begins to scream and struggle.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGIL
dialogues.text: Rev'runt! What is it? O'BANION (screaming) My foot! My foot! VIRGIL lunges to him and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A medium-sized trap- something in which one might reasona catch a wild cat or a coydog, let us say- has its rusty teeth sunk deeply into the reverend's ankle.

dialogues.speaker: O'BANION, (SCREAMING)
dialogues.text: Get it off me! Get it off me! VIRGIL (flustered) Sure...okay... He kneels down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He muscles the trap open, a little at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relaxing. SOUND: THE WOLF HOWLING CLOSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Startled and unnerved by the HOWL, the trap slips out of hands and snaps shut on O'BANION'S mangled ankle again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It slides behind a cloud. SOUND: THE WOLF HOWLING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDY, BILLY McCLAREN, BOBBY ROBERTSON, OWEN KNOPFLER, and MAGGIE ANDREWS have been joined by two other men- MR. ASPINALL and EDGAR ROUNDS. They have drawn close together, listening as the HOWL FAD We can tell by their uneasy faces that some of the joy ha gone out of the evening. They are standing on one side of a ravine. The bottom is filled with a still ground mist. A few bushes poke out of it. There are woods on the far side. ANDY (pointing across) It came from over there.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY ROBERTSON
dialogues.text: As far as I could tell, it could have come from anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: We'll spread out in a skirmish line. If the bastard tries to go around us, we'll hear him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I dunno-

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I think Bobby Robertson here's making lemonade in his pants. That lemonade got ice cubes in it, Bobby? ANDY FAIRTON and EDGAR ROUNDS laugh. ASPINALL and BILLY McCLAREN smile a little. OWEN (quietly) Let off him, Maggie. I'm scared, too. BOBBY (stoutly) I ain't scared! Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Okay. Spread out on me. Five feet apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reading from right to left: OWEN KNOPFLER (his gun is sti over his shoulder; it is the peacemaker baseball bat he i holding), BOBBY ROBERTSON, ASPINALL, ANDY FAIRTON, BILLY McCLAREN, EDGAR ROUNDS and MAGGIE ANDREWS. They come slowly down toward THE CAMERA, alert and ready anything- at least, they think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the bottom of the ravine and begin to make the way across it. The mist is waist to chest deep. They push toward the other side. Now they are about halfway. SOUND: A STEADY, LOW GROWLING, CLOSE. They all stop, scared. BILLY McCLAREN Where's it coming from? Other side?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No- it's behind us. I told you you couldn't trust-

dialogues.speaker: ASPINALL
dialogues.text: It isn't on either side.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: What are you- ASPINALL is looking around, his eyes widening with fear.

dialogues.speaker: ASPINALL
dialogues.text: It's under the fog. It's right in with us. The GROWLING STOPS. There's a beat of silence. Then: SOUND: SNARLING...AND A RIPPING CHOMP as dinner is served SOUND: A SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the one screaming, and if he reminds us of O'BANION, that's okay, because ROUNDS has also been caught in a tra He tries to run, stumbles, falls into the ground fog. He goes on screaming. We can see his back for a moment, and then it disappears. SOUNDS OF CRUNCHING AND SCREAMING. ROUNDS SHRIEKS. His hand and arm come up like the hand of drowning man. Then it's gone. ROUNDS is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand there, chest deep in mist, a conspicuous hole the ranks where EDGAR was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY (moaning) I can't move. Christ Jesus, I can't move!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GROWLING STARTS AGAIN. THE CAMERA PANS SLOWLY UP THE LINE. The mist swirls, hiding whatever's beneath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ASPINALL (low) I think we better start backing up, Andy. Real slow. Real- The LOW GROWL rises to a snarl. And from below the mist, snarling and bestial but understandable, mocking ASPINALL voice: WEREWOLF (voice) "Real slow! Real slow! Real slow!"

dialogues.speaker: SOUND
dialogues.text: ASPINALL SHRIEKS and tries to run. He falls into the mist There is another CHOMP. When he flounders up, half his fa is gone. WEREWOLF (voice) "Real slow! Real slow!" A hairy arm rises from the mist and yanks ASPINALL down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They panic and break for it- MAGGIE, BILLY, and ANDY for side, BOBBY and OWEN for the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA IS RUSHING THROUGH THE GROUND MIST- this is li being in an airplane that's skimming the top of a cloud. WEREWOLF (voice; laughing) "Real slow! Real slow! Real slow!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's hit, as an unlucky swimmer might be hit by a shark. whirls around, raising the peacemaker bat.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Come on, then! You want to rock and roll with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment there's nothing- and then the werewolf rises out of it, eyes glaring green, muzzle and pelt slimed wit gore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGGIE (shrieking) Look at it! Holy God, Andy, look at that thing! ANDY (groaning with fear) I don't want to look at it. He runs, while MAGGIE stares, mesmerized, at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WEREWOLF closes in on OWEN, who belts it a good one w the peacemaker. The WEREWOLF swipes at him. OWEN ducks an slams it again. The WEREWOLF roars with anger.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
