dialogues.text: Come on, come on! You want to do the bop? I'll bop you, motherfucker! Come on! The WEREWOLF dives under the ground mist. Uncertain, OWEN begins to back up, holding the bat in his hands. OWEN is jerked down into the mist. He SCREAMS. The peacemaker rises out of the ground mist and comes down. Bonk! The WEREWOLF roars in pain. CHOMPING SOUND. OWEN shrieks. OWEN (voice) Come on, you bastard! The peacemaker rises out of the mist again. The hands holding it are bloody. Blood runs down the bat. It descen Bonk! The WEREWOLF roars again. There is a GURGLING SCREA from OWEN... and then a curious SPLINTERING SOUND as the WEREWOLF sinks its fangs into the bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA MOVES ABOVE as the WEREWOLF moves below, escap down the draw. Pause. SOUND, IN THE B.G.- low but slowly getting louder: congregation singing "Bringing In the Sheaves" to the accompaniment of a pipe organ. WEREWOLF (sing-songy voice) Bringing in the sheaves... bringing in the sheaves... we shall come rejoicing... bringing in the sheaves... THE WEREWOLF FADES OUT; human voices singing the same hym overwhelm it and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an almost exact reprise of #167. Most of the mourner are crying; MRS. BOWIE playing the organ; MARTY'S chair parked at the back. We can see UNCLE AL, MARTY, TAMMY, an MRS. STURMFULLER, exactly as they were at BRADY KINCAID'S funeral; in fact, this seems to be an instant reply of th event. One difference: we can't see BRADY'S coffin. It's below us. The hymn ends.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Kincaid have asked that there be no mass said here this afternoon. They did ask me to say a word of comfort to you if I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits in the first pew. In his grief he looks dead.

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: There is no comfort, Father. Only private justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's thrown off his stride. Beginning to sweat. He's like actor trying to remember his lines.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: Uh, if there's any word of comfort I can give you, it's just this: the face of the beast always becomes known; the time- He looks down. His eyes widen in fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's coffins- plural. Where BRADY'S coffin was formerly, there are now six coffins, smothered with flowe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is badly scared now; sweat is dripping off him.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: The time... the time of the beast always passes. There are answers... ways... ways to... to cope... if we turn to each other... HERB (bestial voice) Father- LOWE looks toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's looking down at something in his hands. Now he looks and we see his face has become bestial. His eyes are gree As we look at him, the transformation cotinues. He's turn into a werewolf. HERB (snarling) It tore out his heart. And sure enough, HERB KINCAID holds BRADY'S dripping hear up in what were hands but which are now rapidly becoming paws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He staggers back, in terror. LOWE (shrieks) No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. BOWIE begins bringing in a few more sheaves on the church organ, and the congregation begins to sing.

dialogues.speaker: CONGREGATION
dialogues.text: Sowing in the morning/sowing seeds of kindness/sowing in the noontide/and the dewy eve... We pan their faces, stopping on JOE HALLER. Now something happening to JOE'S face. It is bulging, changing. He look up from his hymnal and his eyes glare green. The pupils a split. He grins, showing big teeth. They are all changing. Among the things we see are: PETE SYLVESTER, who is a church deacon, rushing down the aisle, changing, snarling. He grabs ANDY FAIRTON and the of them grapple in the aisle. A YOUNG WOMAN with a baby in her arms turns back the blan covering the baby's face and we see it's a wolfling; alre the YOUNG WOMAN'S own hands are turning into claws. TAMMY STURMFULLER changing; PELTZER the druggist changing the ZINNEMAN BROTHERS changing. At the organ, MRS. BOWIE is now a werewolf clad in tatter of a silk bombazine dress; she/it is still wearing a veil hat on her head, and she is beating the shit out of the organ keys with her clawed hands. She sounds like Jerry L Lewis after swallowing about a dozen bennies. And now the tune changes from the remnants of "Bringing In The Sheave It changes into the Rheingold jingle. CONGREGATION (snarling chorus) My beer is Rheingold the dry beer... Think of Rheingold whenever you buy beer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FATHER LOWE goes stumbling backward, dropping his hymnal. The man is in an extremity of terror.

dialogues.speaker: REV. LOWE
dialogues.text: No! No! No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some are tearing their hymnals apart and throwing them at each other. One guy- BILLY McCLAREN, maybe- wings one of them through a stained-glass window. Some of the werewolv for they are all werewolves now- fight or make love in th aisles. The rest sway back and forth, grinning ferociousl singing. CONGREGATION (snarling it out) It's not bitter, not sweet, it's a real frosty treat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grins ferociously up at him, playing the Rheingold jingle on the pipe organ with her claws. Now blood begins bubble up between the keys.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STURMFULLER AND ALL
dialogues.text: Won't you try, won't you buy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The church is a wild shambles of lurching, fighting, sing werewolves. It's like a New Year's Eve party in hell. CONGREGATION (big finish) ...Rheiinngold beer! Suddenly a clawed hand burts up through one of the coffin And ANDY FAIRTON, who now looks as wolflike as any of the bites the hand's claw off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's seen all he can stand. He whirls for the back, where there is a small door. He pulls it open... and a BRADY KINCAID werewolf, half torn apart but still somehow alive zombie werewolf, if you can dig it- George Romero would l it, I think) leaps out and seizes LOWE. BRADY buries his muzzle in LOWE'S NECK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits up into THE CAMERA and SCREAMS. Sweat is running down his face. He stares at us for a moment, his eyes bug and crazed... and then he closes them. There is an expression of huge relief on his face as he does so. LOWE (praying) Let it end, dear Lord. Let it end. Please let it end.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN STREET DAY
dialogues.text: An old sedan cruises slowly down the street. ANNE and TAM STURMFULLER are in the front seat. It's piled high with possessions and is towing a jackleg trailer with more stu in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HALLER (indifferently) Anne Sturmfuller and her little girl.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah... but what are they doing?

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: Putting on my Sherlock Holmes deerstalker cap, I deduce that they are leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are headed out of town all right, but the thing whic perhaps strikes us the most forcibly is how empty this pl is now. Main Street looks like a ghost town.

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: She's not the only one. Lot of people leaving town. And I guess if we want a beer, we'll have to drink it at home. He nods toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLOSED sign hangs in the door; above it is a big black wreath.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Joe, what's wrong with you? I ain't never seen you like this. HALLER (thoughtful) I lost my guts. PETE (startled) Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: It was the Kincaid boy. I looked at him... and I felt it happen. It was no big deal. No worse than pissing down your own leg. You ever do that? Maybe when you were real scared? PETE, distressed, does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: One minute I had me some guts- as much as the next man, anyhow- and then, poof. Gone. PETE'S looking at him in a kind of terror.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Joe... you are going to feel better than this. This... this feeling of yours... it's gonna pass...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Is it? He walks away, back toward the Municipal Building (the si out front reminds folks to SUPPORT THE MEDCU VAN!) while PETE looks after him, very deeply troubled.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A FAIRGROUND DAY
dialogues.text: It's deserted. Rides stand still. The midway is deserted. THE CAMERA PANS slowly to a sign which reads TARKER'S MIL FAIRGROUNDS GALA FAIR OCTOBER 1 FIREWORKS AT DUSK 10c ON

dialogues.speaker: EVERY DOLLAR GOES TO THE MEDCU VAN FUND
dialogues.text: A cheerful enough sign, except for the strip of paper glu diagonally across it: FIREWORKS CANCELED. MARTY (voice) It's not fair.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE COSLAW FAMILY STATION WAGON DAY
dialogues.text: It's parked across the road from the sign. JANE (voice) Look out, world! Marty the Great didn't get something he wanted! They are distributed just as they were when they arrived this same fairgrounds earlier. All of them have ice cream cones; they are coming home from a family outing.

dialogues.speaker: COSLAW
dialogues.text: Stop it, Jane.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well, I don't see why everybody just about breaks down and cries whenever he-

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Stop it, your mother said. They've just paused for a quick look at the sign; now BOB pulls out onto the road again and heads toward home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE sticks her tongue out at him. MARTY looks away.

dialogues.speaker: THE COSLAW GARAGE DAY
dialogues.text: UNCLE AL'S sports car is parked in the driveway. We hear CLANG of a wrench on the cement inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE GARAGE DAY
dialogues.text: UNCLE AL and MARTY are working on the engine of the Silve Bullet. UNCLE AL has a six-pack of beer that he's working through. He and MARTY sit on the floor. As they talk, UNC AL unscrews the last bolt holding the Bullet's carburetor and pulls it off.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: It isn't enough that the monster killed all those people- that he killed Brady. Now he's got them to cancel the fair.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: And the fireworks. Hand me that box, Marty. MARTY hands him a medium-sized carton with the words "Spe Shop" printed on it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay, the fireworks. Jane thinks that's all I'm mad about, but it's not. Them doing that is just a... a...

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: It's just an outward symbol of everything that's inwardly wrong in this town. Not bad, huh? I read Sherwood Anderson in college. I can jive that shit all day.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Well... I like it that you always know how to say things, Uncle Al.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: I'll give you the telephone numbers of my ex-wives, dear boy- they'll be interested to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Don't call me dear boy.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: But you are, you know- you are my dear boy. He gives MARTY a kiss and smiles at him. MARTY smiles bac

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Look at this. He pulls out a brand-new carburetor- it's a chrome-plated four-barrel. UNCLE AL (gleeful) This is gonna turn your wheelchair into a fucking F-14, Marty- He looks around quickly, guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Your mom's not around, is she?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: She and dad are out back lighting the barbecue. Jane's walking around like she's King Shit of Turd Mountain. Like always.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Only in her case I guess it would be Queen Shit of Turd Mountain. Hand me that adjustable. MARTY does. UNCLE AL slides the carb onto the gasket and starts attaching bolts.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: The guy killed your best friend, drove your girl out of town, and stole the second-best holiday in the year. Have I got it right? MARTY (glum) You got it right, Uncle Al.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Yeah, Winesburg, Ohio, was never like that... but I got something that just might cheer you up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Wait, dear boy. Just wait. Hand me those pliars.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. UNCLE AL, AT THE SIDE OF THE COSLAW HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: He peeks into the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB and NAN are fussing over the barbecue. JANE is hittin badminton birdie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY is sitting in the Silver Bullet. UNCLE AL comes hurrying back from his look-see.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: All is cool, Marty-boy. Go for it. MARTY pushes the starter. The engine starts at once, but tone is entirely different. Before, MARTY'S wheelchair wa poppety-popping pussycat. Now the engine rumbles like a hood's street rod idling at a traffic light. MARTY looks startled. UNCLE AL (grinning) Gun it. MARTY guns it. The engine roars.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Jesus! Not too much! MARTY (awed) Wow.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: You got a pilot's license, Marty?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Do I need one?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: We're gonna find out. Take it down the road a ways and back. Be careful. MARTY puts the Bullet in gear and pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRACKS HIM up the road. He goes slowly at first, b he lets it out a little after a while. He's really moving along- thirty, maybe forty miles an hour. The wind blows hair off his forehead. He begins to grin. He's enjoying this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drinks some beer. He's grinning, happy for MARTY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slows down, turns, stops. He revs the engine. VROOM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of changes back here. It looks almost like a motorc engine now. That chromed-silver carb predominates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grinning. Looking at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about a quarter of a mile away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He winds the engine up and pops the clutch. The Silver Bullet doesn't so much accelerate as blast off. It tilts back on its wheels. MARTY swivels into a position like th of an astronaut on lift-off. The Silver Bullet looks like motorcycle popping a wheelie. MARTY has a great big grin his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roaring down the highway at fifty or better, blue smoke jetting from the exhaust. MARTY is plastered back in the seat with the footrest pointing up at an angle. He's laughing like a lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNCLE AL (to himself) The kid's dead meat. What have I done? (shouts) Put a rock in it, Marty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He uses the hand brakes. SOUND of braking and squealing rubber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Silver Bullet comes to a screeching, sluing stop near UNCLE AL. Blue smoke drifts up from the wheels. MARTY gun the engine once and then lets it idle.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: You gave me a heart attack, Marty. I'm dying. I hope you're happy, because you are looking at a dying man.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: It really goes fast. Thanks, Uncle Al.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: It goes fast, all right- and if your mother finds out just how fast, Marty, I will have a new job. Singing soprano with the Vienna Boys' Choir.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I don't get you.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: I know you don't. But I want this to be our secret. You get that, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last bit of daylight is just filtering away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barbecue is over. BOB and JANE are putting lawn chair on the back porch. MARTY, NAN, and UNCLE AL are all in th f.g.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: I've got to go, Nan- I had a wonderful time. He kisses her cheek affectionately, and she smiles at him

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: So have I, actually... I wish it could always be like this.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: See me around to my car, Marty, and make sure I stay out of trouble at least that long.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Okay. He and UNCLE AL go around to the driveway. NAN looks at t with troubled love.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Now I said I had something for you, as I believe you will recall.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah! What is it? AL unlocks the trunk of his car and brings out a paper shopping bag. He places the bag in MARTY'S lap. MARTY ope the bag, but it's really too dark to see inside. He reach in and brings out a handful of assorted fireworks- cracke Roman candles, twizzers, smoke bombs, etc. An expression of sublime delight fills MARTY'S face as he inventories these goodies.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: You're gonna have the Fourth of July in October, Marty. Just don't blow your head off. (Pause) And remember that it isn't just the fireworks. It's because no crazy shithead should be able to stop the good guys, if you can dig that. MARTY (respectfully) I can dig it- thank you, Uncle Al! Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Stay near the house, for Christ's sake- someone's killing people. I have to be out of my mind to be doing this, you know.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. It's great!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: One of the reasons I love you, Marty, is that you're almost as crazy as I am. Please don't set off anything that goes bang tonight, okay? Just bright colors. Can you tell the difference?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah... sure.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Save this one for last. He brings out a short rocket with stubby vanes on the end fat fuse sticks out behind the head.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: A tracer. You'll like it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Thanks a million, Uncle Al!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: You're welcome a million, Marty. Stick 'em in the bushes for now. MARTY motors over to the side of the garage, where there' line of bushes, and conceals the bag in them. UNCLE AL ge in his car and starts it up. MARTY comes back. UNCLE AL (grinning) Have a good time, dear boy! And watch out for the werewolves! He leaves. MARTY sits in his wheelchair, waving.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE REAR OF THE COSLAW HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: There's a downspout outside one of the upstairs windows. the window goes up and MARTY leans out. He grasps the downspout and begins working his way down. This should no be too hard for us to believe; we've already seen how str MARTY'S arms are. His legs dangle limply, but he's doing just fine. When he reaches the bottom of the drainpipe, they simply crumple under him and he uses his arms to pull himself over to th back porch. MARTY hoists himself over the porch rail. Here, under a tarp, is the Silver Bullet. MARTY pushes the tarp aside a gets in. He uses his hands on the wheels to get over the porch ramp and rolls silently down it. At the bottom he looks up at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still a light on up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY (whispers) Shit! Thinks a bit, then starts to hand-roll the Bullet toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY comes slowly up the path. We hear soft grunts of exertion; he's still hand-turning the wheels for the sake silence, and it's hard work. He stops at the line of bush and gets the bag of fireworks. He puts it on his lap and starts moving again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driveway has a slight downslant, and MARTY coasts eas out to the road. He turns right and begins to roll slowly along the verge of the highway, still using his hands. We can see that the light is still on upstairs. MARTY turns back once to verify this himself, then keeps on going. He not going to be deprived of his treat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He decides he's far enough away to be safe. He pushes the starter button. The engine cranks, coughs, and cranks som more. MARTY frowns, and pulls out a wire- a rudimentary choke, I suppose. He pushes the starter button again. It cranks, but doesn't start. MARTY pushes in the wire, looking concerned now, and trie again. This time, after the engine has cranked over a few times, it starts. MARTY (softly) All right! He puts it in gear and starts off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we see is a tiny boy in a tiny wheelchair moving alo a dark, empty ribbon of road under a vast dome of stars. DISTANT SOUND: The Bullet's engine.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A ROADSIDE TURNOUT NIGHT
dialogues.text: SOUND: Fast-rushing water. The turnout is packed dirt. There's a grove of trees with picnic tables spotted among them at the back. The sign in the extreme f.g. reads ROADSIDE REST AREA at the top; AUG FALLS in the middle; TOWNSHIP OF TARKER'S MILLS at the bottom. SOUND: The Silver Bullet approaching. MARTY turns in and rolls to the back of the rest area. He stops by one of the picnic tables and dumps the bag of fireworks out onto the picnic table and takes his time selecting the first- he's like a wine fancier with a whol cellar of rare bottles to choose from. At last he chooses twizzer. He takes matches from the pocket of his pajama t and lights the fuse. When it starts to fizz, MARTY tosses it high into the air MARTY (soft) Here's one for the good guys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It flies in an arc over the drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA TRACKS ITS FALL onto some rocks at the edge of the waterfall's catch pool. SOUND: Growling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has been drinking from the creek. It looks more than h human now- we would be able to recognize it for sure, but its face is in shadow. It turns from the creek and gets up on its hind legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's guttering out. A hand-paw touches it and draws back quickly. SOUND: Hurt, angry growl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's getting ready to light one of the fountains. He paus and looks toward the cut. He's heard something- but the waterfall muffles it. He lights the fountain's fuse, sets on the ground, and rolls the Bullet back a few feet. The fountain bursts into a shower of light. MARTY (delighted) All right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waterfall is in the b.g. The WEREWOLF is climbing the rocky slope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rolls over to the picnic table and gets a Roman candle He plants the stick in the ground and lights the fuse. Th Roman candle shoots into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bursts into colored light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It GROWLS... and shakes its fists at the fading light in sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's holding another fountain in one hand and his matches the other. He's looking toward the cut and the waterfall.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Is someone there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It freezes, GROWLING FAINTLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a little shrug, he lights the fuse on the fountain a sets it on the ground, as before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claw-hands settle over the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It throws off fiery swirls of sparks, then begins to die down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's checking out the stuff on the table for his next cho when he hears a clear SOUND: A SNAPPING, SPLINTERING BRAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's run into a low-hanging branch. Instead of pushing it aside or ducking under it, it simply rips it off the tree Although the branch is pretty big, the WEREWOLF does this easily as a hungry man might rip a drumstick off a Thanksgiving turkey. It throws the branch aside and advances, hunched over on two legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY (terrified) Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grove is a darkened shadowland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He punches the Bullet's starter. The motor cranks and cranks. No go, though. MARTY pulls out the choke wire, alternating terrified stares at the grove of trees with terrified stares at his rudimentary dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it comes, out of the shadows, closing in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working that starter for all it's worth... but the motor only cranks. Still no start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives up on the motor. He looks toward the picnic tabl where the fireworks are. He grabs up the tracer. He gets matches out of the breast pocket of his p.j.'s and prompt drops them in his lap. He scrabbles for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't see its face in the dark, but it's closer... muc closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to hold the tracer and strike a match at the sam time. He can't; to do that he'd need at least one more hand. He puts the tube of the tracer between his teeth and tries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strikes the match... too hard! It bends, the neck brok MARTY (voice; moaning) Oh, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is in an extremity of terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls a fresh match from the book and strikes it. It lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It recoils- we still can't see its face except for a vagu shadow. (NOTE: I keep emphasizing the shadowed face, because this not a full-moon period. I've been going on the assumption that the guy kind of works his way up to full wolfiness, toothiness, hairiness, etc., starting with a partial chan at about the second quarter. It's a process like the tide coming in. Thus, if we saw MARTY'S attacker clearly at th point, I think we would recognize him.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the tracer from his mouth and applies the match the fuse. It splutters alight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WEREWOLF is less than twenty feet away. The tracer flares alight and shoots out of MARTY'S hand, leaving a pink-orange trail of smoke behind it. The missile flies a the WEREWOLF's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tracer strikes it in the face, and we see a flash of fire. The WEREWOLF screams and blunders away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He punches the starter again. The motor cranks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motor coughs and fires; a big blue flame jumps from t fancy carb... and the engine starts to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's staggering away, ROARING and HOWLING. The tube of th tracer is sticking out of its face- from its left eye, in fact- like an Indian's arrow. The WEREWOLF smashes branch out of its way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wheels the Bullet around and heads for the road, gaspi and weeping with fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's blundering through the trees. It pulls the tube from its face with an ANIMAL SCREAM and drops it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It lies smoldering on the ground. The end is slick with blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bullet is really wheeling. MARTY is panting, out of breath, still deeply frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see it blundering along, holding its face; blood bubbl through its fingers. WEREWOLF (snarling voice) Bastard Marty! Bastard Marty! Kill you! Reeeal slow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He powers up it, and along the path to the back. Perhaps has enough speed to cut the engine and coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His bed is by the window. His hands appear on the windowsill, and MARTY pulls himself in. He falls over ont his bed and lies there, spent and exhausted and trembling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sitting in the "house" wheelchair in the living room holding the phone tensely to his ear as the RINGING SOUND goes on. A CLICK as the phone is picked up. UNCLE AL (muzzy voice) 'Lo? Go away.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: It's a werewolf! I saw it! Last night-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a really spiffy place- the decor is Early American Alcoholic. There's a mostly unclad lady asleep on one sid of the bed. UNCLE AL is sitting on the other in his skivvies, phone to his ear. There are a lot of bottles an heaped ashtrays around, and UNCLE AL has a big old hangov

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: You dreamed it, Marty. MARTY (voice) No! I went out late last night- and-

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: There are no such things as werewolves. Please, dear boy, have some pity. He hangs up and falls back into bed. GIRL (muzzy voice) Whowuzzit?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Obscene phone caller. Go back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sitting on the Silver Bullet, just looking at the ya JANE comes out.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Marty? You okay? You've just been sitting here all morning.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Where's Mom?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Went shopping. Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Jane, I have to talk to you. JANE (mistrustfully) About what? MARTY looks at her earnestly.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I need you to help me. Uncle Al won't believe me, and if you won't help me, I... I... MARTY has to stop. He's almost crying. JANE (concerned) Marty, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE is pushing a supermarket shopping cart with a lot of beer and soda bottles in it. On the side is a sign readin MEDCU BOTTLE AND CAN DRIVE- plus an outline drawing of th Medcu unit. JANE (voice-over) He told me something that was clearly unbelievable... and yet, somehow I believed most of it. And I understood one thing with total clarity: Marty himself believed it all. She turns into a yard and pulls her cart up the walk to t door. She mounts the steps and rings the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sheer curtain at one side of the door is pulled aside a a fearful face- that of MRS. THAYER- looks out. Then we h bolts being pulled and locks- at least three of them- bei unlocked. The lady is taking no chances.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. THAYER
dialogues.text: Jane? JANE (politely) I'm collecting returnable bottles and cans for the Medcu Drive, Missus Thayer- I just wondered if you had any. Her husband comes up the hall.

dialogues.speaker: MR. THAYER
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. THAYER
dialogues.text: Jane Coslaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we see mostly are her eyes- bright, inquiring.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Hi, Mr. Thayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we see mostly are his brown eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MR. THAYER
dialogues.text: Hello, Jane.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. THAYER
dialogues.text: Bring your cart around to the back, Jane- we'll look in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Thank you. She starts down the steps and we

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JANE, ON MAIN STREET DAY
dialogues.text: Amazing how deserted Tarker's Mills looks. JANE is pushin her cart. Even more bottles in it now. JANE (voice-over) Uncle Al hadn't believed him, but Uncle Al was thirty-five that summer and I was fourteen... at fourteen you can still believe the unbelievable, although even then that ability is growing rusty, is preparing to squeal to a stop. She is passing the Holy Family rectory. LESTER LOWE is ou front, digging in his flower garden. He is shirtless, bac to JANE and to us; his black shirt with the turned-around collar hangs informally on a bush. JANE (calls) Hi, Father Lowe! LOWE (without turning) Top of the morning to you, Jane Coslaw!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'm going to bring in a monster load of bottles in an hour or so! LOWE (still digging) That's great, Jane... I'll be waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops at Robertson's Luncheonette, leaves her cart outside, and goes in. THE CAMERA FLOATS TO THE WINDOW; we see JANE explaining about the bottle campaign to BOBBY wh a few men seated at the counter listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide eyes, mostly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mostly eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she turns away, her eyes sweep the men at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of them- PELTZER, VIRGIL CUTTS- are familiar. Others are not. THE CAMERA PANS THEIR FACES CLOSELY, FEATURING THEIR EYES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs the handle of the cart again and proceeds down Main Street. She goes into the barber shop. JANE (v-o) Marty had seen where the tracer had struck home, he said, and I went out that day doing more than just looking for returnable cans and bottles- I was looking for a man- or woman- with only one eye.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE BARBER SHOP DAY
dialogues.text: As JANE enters, BILLY McCLAREN is giving one man a trim. Another man is tipped back with his face wrapped in a tow Two or three other townies are waiting on tonsorial beautification, reading magazines. None, of course, has o one eye. JANE checks them all out carefully.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I know what you're after, Jane, and you're out of luck. Little Toby Whittislaw was in yesterday, and I gave 'em all to him.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh... okay. But her eyes have fixed on the towel over the face of the man in the other barber chair. She walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: That you, Mr. Fairton? ANDY FAIRTON (muffled) No- it's Ronald McDonald. I came in for a shave and a burger. The men laugh. JANE smiles politely. And pulls the hot to away from his eyes. His two eyes. JANE (sweetly) Got any bottles, Mr. Fairton?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: No! JANE (just as sweet) Oh... okay. She puts the towel back and THE CAMERA FOLLOWS as she returns to the door.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: 'Bye, Mr. McClaren. BILLY (amused) 'Bye, Jane. ANDY (muffled) Jesus! JANE goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes the shopping cart up to the gate, opens it, an goes up the walk to the foot of LOWE'S porch steps. She leaves it there and climbs to the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen door is shut, the inner wooden door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark and empty. SOUNDS in the kitchen. EATING SOUNDS, may or maybe we can't tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knocks on the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Father Lowe! I'm ready to turn in my bottles and cans!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOWE is standing by the refrigerator door. He's holding a raw leg of lamb and tearing at it with his teeth. Lamb bl smears his face and runs down his arms. He is as human as you or me (in a manner of speaking, as UNCLE AL would say but when JANE speaks, his head snaps up and his eye flare his one eye. The other is covered by a patch. JANE (voice) Father?

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: Take your cart around to the garage and unload, Jane! Then bring me your tally sheet!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Okay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes down the steps and starts to push the cart aroun the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to the window over the kitchen sink, the blood chunk of meat still in his hands, and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes the cart along a path toward a combination gar and utility shed at the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still watching JANE, he begins to gnaw ravenously at the meat again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door and slowly pushes her cart inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a creepy little place, now filled with bottles an cans that have been crammed in helter-skelter, every whic way. JANE obviously doesn't like it. She begins to unload her cart rapidly, mumbling numbers to herself. SOUND: SQUEAKING. JANE looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good-sized mouse comes out from between a pile of stack bottles and runs across JANE'S shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She utters a litle scream and shrinks back against the wa bumping it quite hard. Hard enough to knock something off overhead shelf. It falls into the bottles, SHATTERING several. JANE screams again- not terribly loud- and then slowly bends toward the object and picks it up. JANE holds it, both puzzled and scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE approaches it, holding a piece of paper in her hand- her tally sheet. She knocks. Waits. There is no answer. S knocks again. Waits. No answer. She tries the door. It opens.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Father Lowe? No answer. After a moment of interior debate, JANE enters the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks around. No one here. But there is a bloody spot the counter- LOWE must have set his grisly luncheon down here for a moment. She walks slowly across the kitchen an into the dark hall.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Father Lowe?... I've got my tally sheet... Farther into the hall. A hand drops onto her shoulder. LOWE (voice) Very good, Jane! She jumps, and so do we. She turns around and looks up at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Featuring his eyes- his eye, rather. The left is covered with a black eye-patch. LOWE (grins) Good, Jane. Very... very good. He holds his hand out, and JANE puts the tally sheet in i like one in a dream. She can't take her eyes off that bla patch, which tells her everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOWE (concerned) Jane! You're trembling!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I... I don't feel so well, I guess maybe I got too much sun.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: Would you like to come in the parlor and lie down for a bit? Or have a cold drink? I have some soda-

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No! (softer) That is, I have to get home and help my mom with lunch.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: I'll give you a ride! JANE is retreating down the hall toward the front door.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No- she... she was going to meet me at the market. I'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much does he know? How much has he guessed? Hard to t from his face, which now seems sinister, with its eye-pat

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: Give my best to your brother, Jane.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I will. She bolts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA HOLDS ON HIM, standing silent and enigmatic. LOWE (soft) Real slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are wide. He's leaning forward in his wheelchair MARTY (almost moaning) Oh, Jeez! What did you do then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's changed into shorts and a blouse.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I ran faster than I ever ran in my life- what do you think, dummox? By the time I got back here, I really thought I was going to faint. (Pause) What are we going to do, Marty? If we tried to tell anybody- grown-ups, I mean- they'd laugh. What are we going to do? MARTY (thoughtfully) I think I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand- MARTY'S- comes into the frame and prints: I KNOW YOU ARE, AND I KNOW WHAT YOU ARE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sitting at his desk, a pool of light from the lamp focused on the sheet of paper before him. He thinks a moment, then begins to write again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is adding: WHY DON'T YOU KILL YOURSELF?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies this for a second, and seems satisfied. He ope a drawer, brings out an envelope, and folds his letter in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has the letter in her hand. She approaches the mailbo opens the mailbox door, and then glances at the envelope again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Addressed in pencil, it says: FATHER LESTER LOWE/HOLY FAM RECTORY; 149 MAIN STREET/TARKER'S MILLS, MAINE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drops the letter in with the air of a girl lighting t fuse on a packet of high explosives. She turns away towar home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's standing at the window and looking out. The torn-ope envelope is on an end table beside him. He's holding the lined sheet of paper in his hand. An expression of bitter hate twists his features, and he slowly crumples the pape in his fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drops in another letter and walks away. JANE (v-o) I mailed another letter for Marty the next day... a third the day after that. Then, on Saturday...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parked at the curb is UNCLE AL'S sports car. JANE (v-o) ...we told Uncle Al what we'd been up to. (Pause) His reaction was less than serene.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Holy-jumped-up-baldheaded-Jesus-CHRIST!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Uncle Al- UNCLE AL (to JANE) From him I'd expect it. I sometimes think his common sense got paralyzed along with his legs. But you, Jane! You! Little Polly Practical! JANE (quiet) You don't understand. UNCLE AL (wildly) Oh, I understand plenty! I understand that my niece and nephew are sending the local Catholic priest little love notes suggesting that he gargle with a broken light bulb or eat a rat-poison omelet!

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: It came for me! I shot it in the eye! Now he's wearing an eye-patch!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: I called Peltzer on my way over here, Marty! Father Lowe came into the drugstore two days ago for a bottle of otic solution. That's a fancy way of saying eyewash. He's got a corneal inflammation.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Was it a prescription?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: What the hell does that matter?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: It wasn't- I'll bet you it wasn't. Because to get a prescription he'd have to see a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Marty, Marty, you should hear yourself!

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Well... was it a prescription?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: I don't know. But I know you didn't see any werewolf the other night, Marty. You had a dream, that's all. An extremely realistic nightmare brought on by what's been happening in this town.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What about the baseball bat Jane saw in his shed? You know who used to have a baseball bat like that? Mr. Knopfler! He was so proud of it he used to carry it in the Fourth of July parade! Jane said it looked like the Green Giant used it for a toothpick!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: You want to know what I think?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: No- we just got you out here so we could admire your pretty face.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Watch it, dear boy. I think it was a hallucination. Probably a broomstick, or something. JANE (indignant) It was not! You want me to show you! Come on! I'm not afraid! I'll show you right now!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: No thank you, Jane. I'm a little old for palying the Hardy Boys Meet the Catholic Werewolf. JANE stamps her foot, furious with UNCLE AL.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Never mind, Jane. He'll have gotten rid of it by now anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Silver Bullet stands outside. The door opens and UNCL AL, JANE, and MARTY come out. UNCLE AL is carrying MARTY piggyback. MARTY has an ice cream cone. JANE is holding t UNCLE AL squats, depositing MARTY in the Bullet. MARTY starts the engine as JANE hands UNCLE AL his ice cream co The three of them start up the street and THE CAMERA TRAC THEM.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: If Father Lowe is an innocent little lamb, why hasn't he picked up the telephone and called Constable Haller to tell him Marty's sending poison-pen letters?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: I don't accept the idea that he knows who his letter writer is, Jane. Because I don't accept the idea that there was a big bad wolf who saw Marty in his wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Why hasn't he picked up the phone and told Constable Haller that someone is sending him poison-pen letters? UNCLE AL stops. He hasn't thought of this. He looks towar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LESTER LOWE is mowing the lawn, eye-patch and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNCLE AL (a bit perplexed) Well... he probably did. I mean, he could make a complaint without taking an ad out in the paper, couldn't he?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I'll bet you a quarter that eyewash stuff was nonprescription. And I'll bet you another quarter he hasn't said anything to Mr. Haller.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Marty, do you see your suspect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeps on moving. MR. ASPINALL drives by and waves. LOWE waves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY (grim) Yes, I see him.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Do you really think that a man who took a rocket in the eye three nights ago could be out mowing his lawn? He'd either be in the hospital... or dead.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I didn't shoot him when he was a man. I shot him when he was-

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: When he was a werewolf. Yes. Right. Jesus. Jane, you don't really believe this madness, do you?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I don't know exactly what I believe. But I know that what I saw was a baseball bat and not a broomstick. I know there was something strange about the way the house smelled that day. It smelled like an animal's den. And I believe in Marty. I mean- there are times when he makes me so mad I could kill him, but I still believe in him. (Pause) You used to believe in him, too, Uncle Al. UNCLE AL looks momentarily ashamed of himself. Then he throws his hands up in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Kids! He walks ahead of them. MARTY bats his eyes sweetly at JA She walks on, miffed. MARTY gooses the Silver Bullet to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A FIELD ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF TOWN DAY
dialogues.text: It's midafternoon. A bunch of kids are playing baseball. the extreme f.g. we see one small boy- MARTY- sitting bac to us in his wheelchair, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It draws slowly along a tree-lined lane and stops. LESTER LOWE is behind the wheel. SOUNDS OF THE BASEBALL GAME CONTINUE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOWE (quietly) Little bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The field team heads in. Kids start streaming back toward town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OUTFIELDER who caught the fly trots past, and glances his way.

dialogues.speaker: OUTFIELDER
dialogues.text: You comin' down to Robertson's for a soda, Marty?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: No- I guess I'll go home. I think that here we are seeing a rare moment of depressi in MARTY- they can run and play ball. He can't.

dialogues.speaker: OUTFIELDER
dialogues.text: Okay- seeya!

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah... seeya. He fires up the Bullet and starts away alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bumps up a grassy slope to a tarred road. The last of other kids are headed back the other way. MARTY is alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It turns out of the lane where it was parked and onto the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY'S back is to us. The wheelchair draws rapidly close to THE CAMERA as LOWE bears down on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans over the wheel, grinning sadistically. LOWE (whispers) Bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's daydreaming his way along- maybe, inside his head, h playing center field for the Dodgers. SOUND: Winding roar of a car engine. MARTY turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY opens the throttle wide and the Bullet swerves acro the road. The coupe's bumper actually clips it on the way by, jolting MARTY and almost overturning the Bullet. LOWE'S coupe veers over the embankment and partway down i the ditch.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: Oh, you bastard! He floors the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spinning helplessly in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He speeds past the coupe, and thumbs his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in a teeth-grinding fury. He jams the gear-shift lev into reverse and floors the gas pedal again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It roars backward in a cloud of ditch dust and bounces on the road. Then it screams out after the rapidly disappear Silver Bullet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hears the GROWLING SOUND of LESTER LOWE'S coupe. He lo behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roars toward THE CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He twists the throttle and the Silver Bullet responds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The director will shoot it as he likes- the basis is simp LOWE is chasing MARTY's hopped-up wheelchair along a coun road at speeds approaching fifty MPH. MARTY should have a couple of near misses, and perhaps we could actually have him pass one car. At one point we should have a REVERSE ANGLE on LESTER LOWE'S coupe, featuring two bumper sticke ATTEND AND SUPPORT YOUR LOCAL CHURCH and HONK IF YOU LOVE

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: As the chase goes on it becomes apparent that LOWE is gaining. MARTY looks increasingly desperate. And now he looks down at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The needle is all the way over on "E."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He groans. SOUND of the coupe's engine GROWS LOUDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOWE charges, rapidly closing the distance. MARTY swerves from one side of the road to the other, escaping LOWE for the moment but almost overturning in the process. They are now running beside a river- the Auger River, in fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the needle is actually past "E."

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Come on, baby... come on... His face registers hope as he sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He twists the throttle as far as it will turn- he's going for broke. The coupe chases him- and now the Silver Bulle motor COUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pretty ramshackle. A big orange sign beside it reads

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY brakes, hits the shoulder of the road, and somehow makes the turn. We see him holding on for dear life as th Silver Bullet bounces and jounces down the dirt road to t mouth of the covered bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It overshoots the right turn MARTY just took, screeches t halt, backs up, and turns onto the lane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It bounces up the incline to the bridge, MOTOR COUGHING A SPLUTTERING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It comes to a sliding, dirt-digging stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face is so full of frustrated hate that it has become the face of a gargoyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dim and spooky in here. Cracks between the boards of the side walls allow dusty fingers of daylight to shine through. More light rays up from the cracks in the floor. The floorboards are warped and uneven; MARTY'S wheelchair sways drunkenly from side to side. The total inside passa is about seventy feet. About halfway across, the Silver Bullet coughs its last cough and splutters its last splutter. It rolls along silently, going on its dying momentum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drawing closer. We hear the SOUNDS of boards rumbling und the Silver Bullet's tires and the Auger River beneath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rolling ever more slowly, the Silver Bullet approaches TH CAMERA... and stops. MARTY is covered with sweat. His hai is in a wild tangle. He's panting. He looks at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an extremely rustic lane. Pretty, but hardly the sort of place in which one would want to find oneself whe one has a part-time werewolf and a full-time homicidal maniac close behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOWE (soft voice) Marty... MARTY'S head whips around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a brilliant square of light. In it stands LOWE'S silhouette. The silhouette begins to move. SOUND of footfalls on the loose floorboards of the covered bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sensible black Oxfords.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry about this. I don't know if you believe that or not, but it's true. I would never willingly hurt a child. You should have left me alone, Marty. SOUND of footfalls resumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's nearly paralyzed with terror- even if he wasn't, he wouldn't get far in a powerless Silver Bullet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOWE (soft; soothing) I can't kill myself, Marty. You see, our religion teaches that suicide is the greatest sin a man or a woman can commit. Stella Randolph was going to commit suicide; if she had done so, she would be burning in hell right now. By killing her I took her physical life but saved her life eternal. You see, Marty? You see how all things serve the will and the mind of God? You see, you meddling little shit! He begins to walk forward again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's halfway across the bridge now, walking slowly, not hurrying.

dialogues.speaker: LOWE
dialogues.text: You're going to have a terrible accident, Marty. You're going to fall into the river. SOUND: TRACTOR ENGINE. LOWE stops, alert to possible dang

dialogues.speaker: TRACTOR SOUND IS LOUDER.
dialogues.text: MARTY'S face fills with hope. He looks from LOWE toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TRACTOR SOUND gets louder still, and here comes ELMER ZINNEMAN on a John Deere. The tractor is hauling a manure spreader which is mostly empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY (waving madly) Mr. Zinneman! Mr. Zinneman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He draws back a little, and his face is sharp with animal cunning- inside his head he's running a four-minute mile. Stay and try to bluff it out, or beat it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELMER draws the tractor up close to MARTY and swings it around. MARTY looks back at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty. SOUND OF A CAR STARTING, FAINT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY looks back at ELMER.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I ran out of gas.

dialogues.speaker: ELMER
dialogues.text: Spooky in there, ennit? MARTY (with feeling) It sure is! He looks back once more toward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brooding, shadowy. CAMERA HOLDS AND WE

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE COSLAW BACKYARD DAY
dialogues.text: MARTY is talking to UNCLE AL. JANE is behind them, knocki croquet balls through the wickets on the back lawn. MARTY is looking at his Uncle anxiously as JANE strolls over.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Well... it's a lot easier to swallow without the hair and the foaming jaws. Also, I checked on the otic solution. It was counter brand. No prescription needed.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I told you!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Shut up, dear boy- no gloating allowed. JANE (sits down) Did you talk to the constable?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: After Marty called me with his latest Thrilling Tale of Wonder, I did. (Pause) He's had no poison-pen complaints lodged at all.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I told you!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Shut up, Marty. UNCLE AL (reluctantly) There's something else.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY JANE
dialogues.text: What is it?                                        What o

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: I probably shouldn't tell you- you're both hysterical on the subject. I'm starting to feel like a guy handing out free Arthur Murray coupons to victims of the dancing sickness.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Uncle Al, if you don't tell me- He makes strangling gestures. UNCLE AL (reluctant) I went out to that rest area. MARTY (triumph) You found the tracer?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: No... but I found some blood, smeared on a tree trunk in that grove.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: There! You see!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: It could have been anything, Marty.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What about Father Lowe chasing me in his car and trying to run me down? You don't think that was a dream, do you?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: No. UNCLE AL comes over to JANE'S side of the Silver Bullet. looks down at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a scrape and a dent where LOWE'S coupe dented it. There is also a fleck of paint.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Lowe's car-?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Blue. This blue.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three-quarters full. THE CAMERA PANS DOWN to the Tarker's Mills town hall. UNC AL'S sports car is parked out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HALLER is behind his desk, rocked back in his chair, hand laced together behind his head. He's looking at UNCLE AL. There's a silence that draws out for quite some time. In UNCLE AL becomes steadily more uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: That's just about the craziest damn story I've ever heard, Al.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: I know. I could have edited out all of the completely crazy stuff, but I thought you deserved to hear it with the bark on.

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: I appreciate that. Now, the next question: Do you believe any of this? You do, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Let's just say I believe Lester Lowe should be checked out. HALLER rises.

dialogues.speaker: HALLER
dialogues.text: That can be arranged. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE RECTORY NIGHT
dialogues.text: A Chevrolet with TARKER'S MILLS CONSTABLE painted on the side in gold leaf pulls up. JOE HALLER gets out, and as h does there's a business of pulling his pants legs down ov his boots- nice stitched cowboy boots, not black cop's shoes. We want the audience to notice these boots, rememb them- probably HALLER should wear them all through the picture. He goes up the walk. HALLER rings the doorbell. No one comes. HALLER rings the bell again. Waits. No one comes. He leans down and looks through a side window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes down the steps, stands on the path for a moment, then goes over to the shed-garage. He opens the door and looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOWE'S coupe is in there. There's just room for it amid t shadowy piles of bottles and cans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes around to the front of LOWE'S coupe and squats do In the b.g.: a heaped mountain of aluminum beer and soda cans. HALLER feels in his breast pocket and brings out a Zippo. lights it and looks at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the turn-signal lamps is broken. There's a scratch the paint and a dent in the bumper. HALLER'S fingers come into the frame and touch the scratch. They stop, and THE CAMERA ZOOMS IN to a small streak of silvery paint. As MA has a scrape of blue car paint on his wheelchair, so does LOWE have a scrape of silver wheelchair paint on his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes widen. SOUND: SHATTERING ROAR and the CLINK AND TUMBLE of about nine thousand cans as LOWE erupts from under the aluminum scrap heap behind HALLER. He is a mixture of man and werewolf, and quite clearly a beastial version of LOWE. I one hand he holds the remains of OWEN KNOPFLER'S peacemak HALLER starts to turn; LOWE strikes him with the bat. CAM CLOSES IN ON LOWE as the bat rises and falls... rises and falls. We can't see HALLER, and that is probably a mercy, but we can hear the THUD of the bat as it strikes again a again and again.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: UNCLE AL has taken the Coslaw family station wagon today. The three of them are sitting in the grove of trees.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Mr. Haller said he'd check him out, and guess what? No one sees him again!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: And what do you suggest I do about it, dear boy? MARTY slips off his St. Christopher's medallion and hands to UNCLE AL.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I want you to turn this into a silver bullet.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: You're not going to let it go, are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I saw what I saw.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Marty, the moon wasn't even full! JANE (quietly) In the made-up stories, the guy who's the werewolf only changes when the moon is full. But maybe he's really that way almost all the time, only as the moon gets fuller... MARTY (finishes) ...the guy gets wolfier. JANE (hands AL her crucifix) Here. Take mine, too.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Jane... you don't have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Don't tell me what I have to do and what I don't, booger-brains.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Will you marry me, Jane?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Would you kids mind telling me how this guy Lowe became a werewolf to begin with?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe he doesn't know, either.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: No one knows how cancer begins, either- or exactly what it is- but people still believe in it.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: The kid is eleven years old and already he sounds like a Jesuit. A French Jesuit.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I think he's going to come for me. Not just because I know who he is, but because I hurt him. Only I don't think he'll try again as Lowe.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Dear boy, you have gone right out of your mind.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Will you do it? UNCLE AL only looks at him, confused and unsure.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A COUNTRY ROAD, WITH THE COSLAW STATION WAGON DAY
dialogues.text: UNCLE AL is taking the kids home- THE CAMERA TRACKS the wagon for a moment, and then we are looking up the short lane and into a gravel pit. THE CAMERA ZOOMS IN, FAST, on the sandy rear wall. We can see one cowboy boot sticking out of a wall of sand. It's bloody and chewed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE COSLAW DRIVEWAY DAY
dialogues.text: The wagon pulls in.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Please, Uncle Al.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Will you? The St. Cristopher's medal and the crucifix are hanging f the rearview on a fine silver chain. UNCLE AL takes down medal and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: All right. I give up. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: All right! Thanks!                                Thank y

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: If either of you ever tells anyone I even bought a piece of this story, werewolves will be the least of your problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a.) UNCLE AL pulls up to a city store front with a sign reading MAC'S GUNS AND AMMO. He takes out the St. Cristopher's medal, looks at it, and shakes his head, as still ruing his own credulity and stupidity. He goes insi JANE (voice-over) Uncle Al's friend Mac was more than a gunsmith; he was, Uncle Al said, an old-world craftsman, a sort of wizard of weapons. b.) In the gun shop interior, we see UNCLE AL talking to MAC, who really should look like an elderly white wizard- kind of Gandalf figure. In the b.g. window we see a paper skeleton and paper jack-o'-lanterns: our first clue that Hallow's Eve is nearing. UNCLE AL is speaking animatedly, using his hands a lot; we don't know exactly what the tal is, but it must be a whopper. In the course of it, he han the medal and the crucifix to MAC, who tents the silver chains over his fingers and looks at them. JANE (v-o continues) God knows what sort of story my uncle told him, but I think that for men who have been married as often as Uncle Al, invention on short notice becomes something of a specialty. c.) In his workroom, we see MAC spilling boron over the medal and looking closely at the stain. JANE (v-o continues) The gunsmith confirmed the high-grade silver content of my crucifix and Marty's medallion... d.) In a dim shot which makes MAC look more like a sorcer than ever, we see him light an acetylene torch and begin melting the medal and the crucifix in the crucible. THE CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY IN as JANE'S contribution and MARTY'S melt together; they are becoming on and indissoluble. JANE (v-o continues) ...melted them down... e.) We see MAC pouring molten silver into a bullet mold. JANE (v-o concludes) ...and molded them into a silver bullet.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MAC'S GUN SHOP, WITH MAC AND UNCLE AL DAY
dialogues.text: MAC comes out of the back with a small inlaid wooden box. puts it down on the glass counter top.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Here it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAC'S hands open it, disclosing a single bullet resting o dark velvet plush. It is a .22 short round, and it gleams pure silver. It would be great to hype this bullet optically- not much, just a little- to make it look absolutely magical. Almost holy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNCLE AL picks up the bullet almost reverently, holds it the light.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Nicest piece of work I ever did, I think. It's got a low-grain load so it won't tumble. Should be pretty accurate.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: It's just a gag, that's all. What would you shoot a silver .22 bullet at, anyway? MAC (joking) How about a werewolf? (Pause) Happy Halloween, Al.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It nearly fills the screen, swimming mysteriously in the warm summer air. JANE (voice-over) By the time Marty's silver bullet was done, it was Halloween... and the full moon had come around again. Earlier that afternoon, my grandfather, who had been dying of cancer for over seven years, finally finished the job. THE CAMERA PANS DOWN to the COSLAW house. There's a carve jack in the window and a corsage of Indian corn on the do UNCLE AL'S MG is in the driveway. The COSLAW station wago is just backing out. UNCLE AL and JANE stand in the doorw MARTY is slightly behind them in the Silver Bullet. NAN leans out of the car. She's wearing black, and she ha obviously been crying.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: Remember, Al... we'll be at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston tomorrow night! Or at the funeral parlor. It's Stickney and-

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: -and Babcock, I remember. Now go on! The station wagon backs farther and NAN leans out again.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: And don't open the door for any trick or treaters even if they come!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: We won't! The station wagon backs out into the road and NAN pops ou again.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: You kids go to bed on time! You've got school tomorrow!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: If you keep doing that, you're going to bump your head, sissy. Give my love to Mama- tell her I'll see her Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: I will- be good, kids.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: 'Bye, mom! Bye, dad!                                We wi The station wagon accelerates away.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Can I tell you kids something?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Sure, Uncle Al.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: When me and sissy were kids, we were just like you two.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Yeah? Really?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Really. The bitch of it is, we still are. Learn from your elders, dearies. He ushers them inside and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I can't believe that you'd agree to leave the kids with him. A year ago I would have laughed at the idea. You used to almost breathe fire when Al came in the house.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: He's changed. Just this summer. Or something's changed him. Marty, maybe. And the drinking- I think it's almost stopped. Whatever it is, it's wonderful. And they'll be safe with him. I'm sure of it.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I know they'll be safe with him... but will he get them both into bed by nine-thirty? NAN (firmly) If I told him to, he will.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE WALL CLOCK IN THE COSLAW LIVING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: It reads 1:00. SOUND: The National Anthem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The anthem finishes up. We go to a station ID card.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: This concludes WDML's broadcast day. The TV goes to snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's mostly asleep in one corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's also dozing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is also dozing. There are three or four empty beer can in front of him, and a cigarette with a long ash is smoldering between his fingers. There's a .22 pistol in h lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WEREWOLF breaks from the woods and runs across the si yard to a line of high bushes that runs along the side of the house (this is the opposite side from MARTY'S bedroom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a space in here between the house and the bushes it's like an animal's run. The WEREWOLF creeps along this its one eye flaring. DIM SOUND OF TV SNOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNCLE AL jumps up and cries out as the cigarette burns up his fingers. The .22 falls onto the rug. MARTY and JANE also wake up, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It recoils, eyes gleaming. Foam begins to drip from its jaws. It creeps slowly along toward a window. TV SNOW SOU GROW LOUDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNCLE AL is shaking his burned hand; he picks the cigaret out of his lap and puts it out. JANE (sleepy) You'll burn yourself up sometime doing that, Uncle Al.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: I suppose so. You kids ought to go up to bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: But Uncle Al! You said-

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: I know what I said, Marty- but it's ten past one. He's not coming.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: The moon's not down yet...

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Damn near. Now I'll sit up with this stupid gun in my lap because I promised, but you two are going to bed. Go on, now, scoot. JANE gets up and starts toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What if I say no?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Then I'd have to kick your ass, dear boy. (more kindly) Go on, now. MARTY begins to roll the Silver Bullet toward the stairs, where the stair chair awaits. JANE is waiting for him at living-room doorway. MARTY sees the gun on the floor and stops.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: If that'd gone off, it would have been the end of our silver bullet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He prickles a bit at the unstated criticism. He bends dow and picks up the pistol. He opens the cylinder. Five chambers are empty; in one there's a bright silver circle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes the cylinder plunger, dropping the silver bulle into his hand.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: See, dear boy? Totally unimpaired. Behind him, the WEREWOLF'S head appears in the window, it green eye flaring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY, looking toward UNCLE AL, sees nothing. JANE is looking toward the window and she SCREAMS. JANE (shrieking) It's him! It's the werewolf! I see him!

dialogues.speaker: IT'S THE WEREWOLF
dialogues.text: She's pointing at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps up and looks around at the window- at this point has the .22 with its cylinder open in one hand and the silver bullet loosely held in the other. Nothing in the window but darkness. UNCLE AL turns back t the kids. UNCLE AL (sharply) You see it, Marty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTY (shakes his head) I was looking at you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His shoulders slump a little with relief- now that the sc is over, his relief is tempered with irritation. They're just a couple of hysterical kids after all, and JANE is actually worse than MARTY. Polly Practical indeed!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: A very familiar feeling is beginning to creep over me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE is crying.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What's that, Uncle Al?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: I feel like a horse's ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE (weeping) I saw it, Uncle Al! I did! MARTY rolls a little closer to her and attempts to put a comforting arm around her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Don't you touch me, snotbrains!

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Jane-

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Would you kids go to bed? My head's starting to ache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a clawed, hairy hand reach into the frame and clos around a thick wire. WEREWOLF (voice) Reeeal slow... It yanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights go out. JANE SHRIEKS.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: It's here! It's outside!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE AL
dialogues.text: Jane, it's just a power fai- He's starting toward her. At that moment most of the wall not just the window it was looking through before but the whole wall- crashes inward as the WEREWOLF bulls its way through, roaring. UNCLE AL whirls, raising the pistol automatically to fire but the cylinder is rolled out and all the chambers are empty. He has time to register surprise before the WEREWO smashes him aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes flying backward. The pistol goes one way, the sil bullet another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It spins into a living-room corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see it rise in the air, turning over and over. It come down, hits the floor, and rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the extreme f.g. is a heating vent. The bullet is roll toward it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Get the gun! He uses his hands to propel the ungainly Silver Bullet in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silver bullet rolls slowly toward the heating vent. I the b.g. we see a frantic MARTY in his wheelchair. He heaves himself out of it and falls full-length, grabbi His fingers touch the bullet, but that's all. It falls in the heating vent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's roaring, furious, its one eye flaring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNCLE AL lies senseless against one wall, the front of hi shirt bloody. JANE runs into the corner and grabs the pistol. The WEREWOLF picks up the easy chair and throws it throug the hole it made coming in. It picks up an end table and hurls it through the TV. Then it sees JANE and starts tow her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comes toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes as if to run one way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a couple of feet from her now, but again, it is toying with her- it's making this reeeal slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bloodstained hand grabs a poker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it tenses down to leap at her, UNCLE AL leaps at it an strikes it across the back. It turns, ROARING. UNCLE AL hits it between the legs. It BELLOWS and grabs the poker. It bends it and tosses it aside. The glaring, savage expression on its face says th now it will bend UNCLE AL and toss him aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breaks out of the corner and runs across the room tow the door. Most of the way there she trips and falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its head whips around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lying full-length. He's got the heater vent's grille off. One arm is down inside. MARTY (scream) Janey! The gun! THE GUN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tosses it awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It slides down the hall floor to MARTY like some strange, awkward shuffleboard disc, its cylinder still open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WEREWOLF (snarls) Maa-aaa-rty... It begins walking slowly across the living room, smashing things out of its way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gun slides into his hand. Now he reaches into the heating duct again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
